<ce:caption id="ca0045">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0085" view="all">A. Percent change of cell survival in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, following treatment with various concentrations (1–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) of KVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Sodium deoxycholate was used as a positive control. Values represent the mean value of three independent experiments. Vertical bars represent SEMs. B. Percent change of cell survival in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes following treatment with various concentrations (1–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H (B-1), L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H (B-2) or L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H (B-3) for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control. Values represent the mean value of several (no less than triplicate) different experiments. Vertical bars represent standard deviation. *p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05 vs. control.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

Percent change of cell survival in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes following treatment with various concentrations (1-200μΜ) of L1H (B-1), L2H (B-2) or L3H (B-3) for 24h. Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control. Values represent the mean value of several (no less than triplicate) different experiments. Vertical bars represent standard deviation. *p<0.05 vs. control.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="sch0005">
<ce:label>Scheme 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="ca0075">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0125" view="all">Schematic representation of the ligands (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H) used in this study. The hydrogen in the adopted formulation signifies the presence of the phenolic hydrogen. The additional hydrogen originating in the alcoholic moieties of the ligands and removed upon deprotonation is dubbed H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>, thereby leading to [L<ce:inf loc="post">i</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> (i<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1–3) ions in the emerging vanadium complex assemblies.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link id="lk0065" locator="sc1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Scheme 1  Schematic representation of the ligands (L1H, L2H, L3H) used in this study. The hydrogen in the adopted formulation signifies the presence of the phenolic hydrogen. The additional hydrogen originating in the alcoholic moieties of the ligands and removed upon deprotonation is dubbed H-1, thereby leading to [LiH-1]2- (i=1-3) ions in the emerging vanadium complex assemblies.

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Among the various roles of vanadium in the regulation of intracellular signaling, energy metabolism and insulin mimesis, its exogenous activity stands as a contemporary challenge currently under investigation and a goal to pursue as a metallodrug against Diabetes mellitus II. In this regard, the lipogenic activity of vanadium linked to the development of well-defined anti-diabetic vanadodrugs has been investigated through: a) specifically designing and synthesizing Schiff base organic ligands L, bearing a variable number of terminal alcohols, b) a series of well-defined soluble binary V(V)-L compounds synthesized and physicochemically characterized, c) a study of their cytotoxic effect and establishment of adipogenic activity in 3T3-L1 fibroblasts toward mature adipocytes, and d) biomarker examination of a closely-linked molecular target involving or influenced by the specific V(V) forms, cumulatively delineating factors involved in potential pathways linked to V(V)-induced insulin-like activity. Collectively, the results a) project the importance of specific structural features in Schiff ligands bound to V(V), thereby influencing the emergence of its (a)toxicity and for the first time its insulin-like activity in pre-adipocyte differentiation, b) contribute to the discovery of molecular targets influenced by the specific vanadoforms seeking to induce glucose uptake, and c) indicate an interplay of V(V) structural speciation and cell-differentiation biological activity, thereby gaining insight into vanadium's potential as a future metallodrug in Diabetes mellitus.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Among the various roles of vanadium in the regulation of intracellular signaling, energy metabolism and insulin mimesis, its exogenous activity stands as a contemporary challenge currently under investigation and a goal to pursue as a metallodrug against Diabetes mellitus II. In this regard, the lipogenic activity of vanadium linked to the development of well-defined anti-diabetic vanadodrugs has been investigated through: a) specifically designing and synthesizing Schiff base organic ligands L, bearing a variable number of terminal alcohols, b) a series of well-defined soluble binary V(V)-L compounds synthesized and physicochemically characterized, c) a study of their cytotoxic effect and establishment of adipogenic activity in 3T3-L1 fibroblasts toward mature adipocytes, and d) biomarker examination of a closely-linked molecular target involving or influenced by the specific V(V) forms, cumulatively delineating factors involved in potential pathways linked to V(V)-induced insulin-like activity. Collectively, the results a) project the importance of specific structural features in Schiff ligands bound to V(V), thereby influencing the emergence of its (a)toxicity and for the first time its insulin-like activity in pre-adipocyte differentiation, b) contribute to the discovery of molecular targets influenced by the specific vanadoforms seeking to induce glucose uptake, and c) indicate an interplay of V(V) structural speciation and cell-differentiation biological activity, thereby gaining insight into vanadium's potential as a future metallodrug in Diabetes mellitus.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Appropriately designed Schiff-bases promote vanadium binding and afford well-defined V(V)-Schiff ligand compounds. Key structural characteristics of V(V)-bound ligands a) formulate a physicochemically-driven selection of biologically-active complex vanadoforms inducing insulin-mimetic fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes, and b) transcribe structure-specific biomarker-tagged vanadium adipogenic activity potentiating vanadodrug development in Diabetes mellitus II.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0075" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Appropriately designed Schiff-bases promote vanadium binding and afford well-defined V(V)-Schiff ligand compounds. Key structural characteristics of V(V)-bound ligands a) formulate a physicochemically-driven selection of biologically-active complex vanadoforms inducing insulin-mimetic fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes, and b) transcribe structure-specific biomarker-tagged vanadium adipogenic activity potentiating vanadodrug development in Diabetes mellitus II.

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0175" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0400" view="all">Design of Schiff base organic substrates bearing varying number of alcohol moieties</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0405" view="all">Synthesis and physicochemical characterization of binary V(V)-Schiff base compounds</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0410" view="all">Insulin-mimetic V(V)-induced fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0020">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0415" view="all">Biomarker proof of insulin-like well-defined vanadoform lipogenicity in adipocytes</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0025">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0420" view="all">Physicochemically formulated selection of V(V) adipogenicity in anti-diabetic drugs</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Design of Schiff base organic substrates bearing varying number of alcohol moieties   ⋅ Synthesis and physicochemical characterization of binary V(V)-Schiff base compounds   ⋅ Insulin-mimetic V(V)-induced fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes   ⋅ Biomarker proof of insulin-like well-defined vanadoform lipogenicity in adipocytes   ⋅ Physicochemically formulated selection of V(V) adipogenicity in anti-diabetic drugs

Several proteins (trypsin, lectins and anti-bodies to the insulin receptor) and numerous low molecular mass substances, such as H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, zinc, manganese ions and oubain, activate glucose uptake and glucose metabolism in rat adipocytes . elements.clean_text:
Design of Schiff base organic substrates bearing varying number of alcohol moieties

Synthesis and physicochemical characterization of binary V(V)-Schiff base compounds

Insulin-mimetic V(V)-induced fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes

Biomarker proof of insulin-like well-defined vanadoform lipogenicity in adipocytes

Physicochemically formulated selection of V(V) adipogenicity in anti-diabetic drugs

Introduction

Since the discovery of insulin, research has demonstrated its uncontested value in treating diabetes. Nevertheless, researchers, particularly over the past three decades, have been searching for insulin-mimicking agents to assist in the therapy of Diabetes mellitus type II (non-insulin dependent), which accounts for about 90% of diabetic patients . Successful development of methods for the preparation of insulin responsive cells in the 1970s (i.e. rat adipocytes ) facilitated the investigation of the mechanism of insulin action as well as the identification of several agents that mimic insulin actions. Several proteins (trypsin, lectins and anti-bodies to the insulin receptor) and numerous low molecular mass substances, such as H2O2, zinc, manganese ions and oubain, activate glucose uptake and glucose metabolism in rat adipocytes . However, none of them combine the necessary features of absorption, stability in body fluids, low index of toxicity, and specificity in mimicking insulin bioresponses .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">As with other metal ions in biological systems, vanadium is primarily complexed <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic>. It readily associates with proteins such as transferrin, albumin and hemoglobin, as well as with low molecular mass compounds, such as glutathione . In 1980, vanadium salts were demonstrated to mimic the actions of insulin on hexose uptake and glucose metabolism in rat adipocytes. Both externally added vanadate (V(V)) and vanadyl (V(IV)) ions were effective in this respect . Researchers examined the insulin-like actions of vanadium salts in a large variety of insulin-responsive cells and tissues. It turned out that vanadium salts mimic most of the known rapid metabolic effects of insulin on the main tissues of the hormone <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic>. Vanadium salts activate hexose transport in adipose and muscle tissues though at relatively high concentrations (ED<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM) . The collective work led to the realization that vanadium therapy induces normoglycemia and improves glucose homeostasis in insulin deficient and insulin resistant diabetic rodents . The key mechanisms involved are inhibition of protein-phosphotyrosine phosphatases and activation of non-receptor protein-tyrosine kinases, in an insulin-receptor tyrosine kinase independent fashion . Vanadate activates glucose-metabolism <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> at a site preceding activation of phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3-kinase) . With regard to the inhibition of lipolysis, vanadate acts at a site downstream to the activation of PI3-kinase . Vanadate inhibits several key metabolic enzyme systems in liver, muscle and adipose tissues, all of which act collectively toward utilizing or storing cell-entered glucose as well as blocking the actions of hormones that oppose insulin action .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As with other metal ions in biological systems, vanadium is primarily complexed in vivo. It readily associates with proteins such as transferrin, albumin and hemoglobin, as well as with low molecular mass compounds, such as glutathione . In 1980, vanadium salts were demonstrated to mimic the actions of insulin on hexose uptake and glucose metabolism in rat adipocytes. Both externally added vanadate (V(V)) and vanadyl (V(IV)) ions were effective in this respect . Researchers examined the insulin-like actions of vanadium salts in a large variety of insulin-responsive cells and tissues. It turned out that vanadium salts mimic most of the known rapid metabolic effects of insulin on the main tissues of the hormone in vitro. Vanadium salts activate hexose transport in adipose and muscle tissues though at relatively high concentrations (ED50 =100-200μM) . The collective work led to the realization that vanadium therapy induces normoglycemia and improves glucose homeostasis in insulin deficient and insulin resistant diabetic rodents . The key mechanisms involved are inhibition of protein-phosphotyrosine phosphatases and activation of non-receptor protein-tyrosine kinases, in an insulin-receptor tyrosine kinase independent fashion . Vanadate activates glucose-metabolism in vitro at a site preceding activation of phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3-kinase) . With regard to the inhibition of lipolysis, vanadate acts at a site downstream to the activation of PI3-kinase . Vanadate inhibits several key metabolic enzyme systems in liver, muscle and adipose tissues, all of which act collectively toward utilizing or storing cell-entered glucose as well as blocking the actions of hormones that oppose insulin action .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Preliminary clinical studies using vanadium have been previously performed, with several beneficial effects having been documented. The potential use of vanadium in the future care of diabetes in human, however, rests on careful fine-tuning that would elevate the insulin-mimetic efficacy of vanadium without increasing its toxicity. To this end, various organic ligand-bound vanadium compounds emerged as more potent than free vanadium salts in facilitating insulin-like effects <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Preliminary clinical studies using vanadium have been previously performed, with several beneficial effects having been documented. The potential use of vanadium in the future care of diabetes in human, however, rests on careful fine-tuning that would elevate the insulin-mimetic efficacy of vanadium without increasing its toxicity. To this end, various organic ligand-bound vanadium compounds emerged as more potent than free vanadium salts in facilitating insulin-like effects in vitro and in vivo .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">For new anti-diabetic drugs containing V(IV,V) and fulfilling the basic criteria of a) atoxic behavior, b) optimal insulin-mimetic activity, and c) capability of crossing plasma-membranes through naturally occurring transport systems, organic ligands–substrates are poised to play a significant role, thereby attracting attention as potential V(IV,V) binders . Among such organic reagents, Schiff bases possess structural similarities with natural biological substances, relatively simple preparation procedures, and synthetic flexibility enabling design of suitable (bio)chemical reactivity properties . They have been widely studied , because of their role as intermediates in a number of enzymatic reactions and non-enzymatic glycosylations , and their industrial, anti-fungal, anti-bacterial, anti-cancer, anti-diabetic, anti-viral and herbicidal applications .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For new anti-diabetic drugs containing V(IV,V) and fulfilling the basic criteria of a) atoxic behavior, b) optimal insulin-mimetic activity, and c) capability of crossing plasma-membranes through naturally occurring transport systems, organic ligands-substrates are poised to play a significant role, thereby attracting attention as potential V(IV,V) binders . Among such organic reagents, Schiff bases possess structural similarities with natural biological substances, relatively simple preparation procedures, and synthetic flexibility enabling design of suitable (bio)chemical reactivity properties . They have been widely studied , because of their role as intermediates in a number of enzymatic reactions and non-enzymatic glycosylations , and their industrial, anti-fungal, anti-bacterial, anti-cancer, anti-diabetic, anti-viral and herbicidal applications .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Guided by the idea that properly designed Schiff bases may promote V(IV,V) binding, thereby giving rise to bioactive insulin-mimetic compounds capable of inducing normal blood glucose levels, efforts were launched to a) design new Schiff base organic substrates bearing systematically varying structural features reflected in a varying number of alcohol moieties attached to a vanillin core (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), b) synthesize binary V(IV,V)-Schiff base compounds of specific structure and characterize them physicochemically, c) investigate the insulin-mimetic potency of such compounds toward cellular differentiation of 3T3-L1 fibroblasts to mature adipocytes, d) investigate the interactions of such molecules with specific molecular targets in the insulin-induced glucose catabolic pathways known to date, and e) correlate chemical and structural features of the binary V(IV,V) compounds with the observed biological activities at the cellular level, thereby formulating biological activity profile-physicochemical factor relationships that enable development of optimal V(IV,V) insulin-mimetic drugs. Hence, we report herein the synthesis and physicochemical characterization of a series of well-defined binary V(V)-Schiff base compounds, which a) are systematically studied with respect to their insulin-mimetic activity toward fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes, and b) conform to the aforementioned attributes formulating structure-specific biologically-linked knowledge key to developing efficient vanadodrugs in Diabetes mellitus II.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Guided by the idea that properly designed Schiff bases may promote V(IV,V) binding, thereby giving rise to bioactive insulin-mimetic compounds capable of inducing normal blood glucose levels, efforts were launched to a) design new Schiff base organic substrates bearing systematically varying structural features reflected in a varying number of alcohol moieties attached to a vanillin core ( ), b) synthesize binary V(IV,V)-Schiff base compounds of specific structure and characterize them physicochemically, c) investigate the insulin-mimetic potency of such compounds toward cellular differentiation of 3T3-L1 fibroblasts to mature adipocytes, d) investigate the interactions of such molecules with specific molecular targets in the insulin-induced glucose catabolic pathways known to date, and e) correlate chemical and structural features of the binary V(IV,V) compounds with the observed biological activities at the cellular level, thereby formulating biological activity profile-physicochemical factor relationships that enable development of optimal V(IV,V) insulin-mimetic drugs. Hence, we report herein the synthesis and physicochemical characterization of a series of well-defined binary V(V)-Schiff base compounds, which a) are systematically studied with respect to their insulin-mimetic activity toward fibroblast differentiation to mature adipocytes, and b) conform to the aforementioned attributes formulating structure-specific biologically-linked knowledge key to developing efficient vanadodrugs in Diabetes mellitus II.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0180">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">All experiments were carried out under aerobic conditions. The structures of the ligands used are shown in . The following starting materials were purchased from commercial sources (Sigma, Fluka) and were used without further purification: a) tromethamine, 2-amino-1,3-propanediol, ethanolamine, o-vanillin, sodium hydroxide, and vanadyl acetylacetonate [VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]; and b) solvents: ultrapure water, methanol, and ethanol. The isolated and dried under vacuum at room temperature complexes are air-stable. All three Schiff bases (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H) were synthesized as prototypes according to the literature . Their synthetic assembly, however, during the vanadium complex synthesis (vide infra) was carried out <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and methods

All experiments were carried out under aerobic conditions. The structures of the ligands used are shown in . The following starting materials were purchased from commercial sources (Sigma, Fluka) and were used without further purification: a) tromethamine, 2-amino-1,3-propanediol, ethanolamine, o-vanillin, sodium hydroxide, and vanadyl acetylacetonate [VO(C5H7O2)2]; and b) solvents: ultrapure water, methanol, and ethanol. The isolated and dried under vacuum at room temperature complexes are air-stable. All three Schiff bases (L1H, L2H, L3H) were synthesized as prototypes according to the literature . Their synthetic assembly, however, during the vanadium complex synthesis (vide infra) was carried out in situ.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0185">Physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">FT-Infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer 1760X FT-infrared spectrometer. UV–visible (UV–vis) measurements were carried out on a Hitachi U2001 spectrophotometer in the range from 190 to 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. A Thermo Finnigan Flash EA 1112 CHNS elemental analyzer was used for the simultaneous determination of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen (%). The analyzer operation is based on the dynamic flash combustion of the sample (at 1800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) followed by reduction, trapping, complete GC separation and detection of the products. The instrument is a) fully automated and controlled by PC via the Eager 300 dedicated software, and b) capable of handling solid, liquid or gaseous substances. The morphology and chemical composition of the products with respect to vanadium were determined with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV JEOL 840A SEM equipped with an Oxford ISIS 300 EDS analyzer. For the SEM examination, the surface of the samples did not undergo any preparation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

FT-Infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer 1760X FT-infrared spectrometer. UV-visible (UV-vis) measurements were carried out on a Hitachi U2001 spectrophotometer in the range from 190 to 1000nm. A Thermo Finnigan Flash EA 1112 CHNS elemental analyzer was used for the simultaneous determination of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen (%). The analyzer operation is based on the dynamic flash combustion of the sample (at 1800°C) followed by reduction, trapping, complete GC separation and detection of the products. The instrument is a) fully automated and controlled by PC via the Eager 300 dedicated software, and b) capable of handling solid, liquid or gaseous substances. The morphology and chemical composition of the products with respect to vanadium were determined with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a 20kV JEOL 840A SEM equipped with an Oxford ISIS 300 EDS analyzer. For the SEM examination, the surface of the samples did not undergo any preparation.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) infusion experiments were carried out by using a Thermo Fisher Scientific (Bremen, Germany) model LTQ Orbitrap Discovery MS. L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H was dissolved in water and introduced into the ESI source of the MS at a flow rate of 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL/min by using an integrated syringe pump. The infusion experiments were run using a standard ESI source operating in a positive ionization mode. Source operating conditions were a 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV spray voltage and a 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C heated capillary temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) infusion experiments were carried out by using a Thermo Fisher Scientific (Bremen, Germany) model LTQ Orbitrap Discovery MS. L2H was dissolved in water and introduced into the ESI source of the MS at a flow rate of 3μL/min by using an integrated syringe pump. The infusion experiments were run using a standard ESI source operating in a positive ionization mode. Source operating conditions were a 3.7kV spray voltage and a 300°C heated capillary temperature.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0035">Solid state NMR</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Solid state cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CPMAS) <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained on a Varian 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz spectrometer operating at 150.86<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz. In each case, a sufficient sample quantity was placed in a 3.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm rotor. A double resonance HX probe was used. The spinning rate was set at 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz. The spectra were recorded with 1000–10,000 scans, using a 90° pulse width of 5.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μs, a contact time of 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ms and a recycle delay of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The CH signal of adamantane was used as an external reference (37.78<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm with respect to tetramethyl silane (TMS)).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solid state NMR

Solid state cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CPMAS) 13C NMR spectra for 1-3 were obtained on a Varian 600MHz spectrometer operating at 150.86MHz. In each case, a sufficient sample quantity was placed in a 3.2mm rotor. A double resonance HX probe was used. The spinning rate was set at 15kHz. The spectra were recorded with 1000-10,000 scans, using a 90° pulse width of 5.4μs, a contact time of 3.0ms and a recycle delay of 5s for 1-3. The CH signal of adamantane was used as an external reference (37.78ppm with respect to tetramethyl silane (TMS)).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The high resolution solid state <ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, were measured at 157.803<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz. The spinning rate used was 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz. High power decoupling was used with a 90° pulse of 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μs. Each solid-state spectrum was a result of the accumulation of 1000 scans and the recycle delay used was 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. All solid-state spectra were referenced to NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, which showed a resonance at −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>514.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm with respect to liquid VOCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The high resolution solid state 51V magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectra of 1-3, were measured at 157.803MHz. The spinning rate used was 12kHz. High power decoupling was used with a 90° pulse of 1.5μs. Each solid-state spectrum was a result of the accumulation of 1000 scans and the recycle delay used was 1s. All solid-state spectra were referenced to NaVO3, which showed a resonance at -514.4ppm with respect to liquid VOCl3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0190">Solution NMR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Solution <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H and <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR experiments for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, were carried out on Varian 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz spectrometer. The sample concentration was ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM. The compounds were dissolved in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Carbon spectra were acquired with 5000 transients, a spectral width of 37,000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz and a relaxation delay of 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. Proton spectra were acquired with 16 transients and a spectral width of 5000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz. Experimental data were processed using VNMR routines. Spectra were zero-filled and subjected to exponential apodization prior to FT. Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm, while the spectra were referenced by the standard experimental setup.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solution NMR spectroscopy

Solution 1H and 13C NMR experiments for 1-3, were carried out on Varian 600MHz spectrometer. The sample concentration was ~5mM. The compounds were dissolved in D2O. Carbon spectra were acquired with 5000 transients, a spectral width of 37,000Hz and a relaxation delay of 2s. Proton spectra were acquired with 16 transients and a spectral width of 5000Hz. Experimental data were processed using VNMR routines. Spectra were zero-filled and subjected to exponential apodization prior to FT. Chemical shifts (δ) are reported in ppm, while the spectra were referenced by the standard experimental setup.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0195">Thermal studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A TA Instruments, model Q 600, system was used to run the simultaneous TGA experiments. The instrument mass precision is 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μg. About 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg of each sample was placed in an open alumina sample pan for each experiment. A mixture of helium and high purity air (80/20 in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) was used at a constant flow rate of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL/min, depending on the conditions required for running the experiments. During the experiments, the sample weight loss and rate of weight loss were recorded continuously under dynamic conditions, as a function of time or temperature, in the range 45–850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Prior to activating the heating routine program, the entire system was purged with the appropriate gas for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, at a rate of 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL/min, to ensure that the desired environment was established. The residues emerging from TGA were subjected to scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis carried out using a JEOL JMS-840A scanning microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) INCA micro-analytical system. Operating conditions were as follows: accelerating voltage 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV, probe current 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nA and counting time 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, with ZAF correction being provided on-line. The samples were coated with carbon, using a JEOL JEE-4X vacuum evaporator.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal studies

A TA Instruments, model Q 600, system was used to run the simultaneous TGA experiments. The instrument mass precision is 0.1μg. About 10mg of each sample was placed in an open alumina sample pan for each experiment. A mixture of helium and high purity air (80/20 in N2/O2) was used at a constant flow rate of 100mL/min, depending on the conditions required for running the experiments. During the experiments, the sample weight loss and rate of weight loss were recorded continuously under dynamic conditions, as a function of time or temperature, in the range 45-850°C. Prior to activating the heating routine program, the entire system was purged with the appropriate gas for 10min, at a rate of 400mL/min, to ensure that the desired environment was established. The residues emerging from TGA were subjected to scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis carried out using a JEOL JMS-840A scanning microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) INCA micro-analytical system. Operating conditions were as follows: accelerating voltage 20kV, probe current 45nA and counting time 60s, with ZAF correction being provided on-line. The samples were coated with carbon, using a JEOL JEE-4X vacuum evaporator.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0040">Preparation of compounds</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0200">Preparation of L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To a solution of o-vanillin (3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.46<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) in methanol (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.27<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was added under stirring. The emerging deep yellow solution was refluxed for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under continuous stirring and then was quickly cooled upon addition of room temperature ultrapure water. A pale yellow material precipitated and was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (37%). Further confirmation of the identity of L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H in solution comes from ESI-MS measurements on solutions arising upon the dissolution of compound L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H in water (m/z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>226.08, z<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, [MH]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>) (Fig. S1).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of compounds

Preparation of L2H

To a solution of o-vanillin (3.0mmol, 0.46g) in methanol (30mL) 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (3.0mmol, 0.27g) was added under stirring. The emerging deep yellow solution was refluxed for 12h under continuous stirring and then was quickly cooled upon addition of room temperature ultrapure water. A pale yellow material precipitated and was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.25g (37%). Further confirmation of the identity of L2H in solution comes from ESI-MS measurements on solutions arising upon the dissolution of compound L2H in water (m/z=226.08, z=1, [MH]+) (Fig. S1).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0205">Preparation of complex {(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) in methanol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) tromethamine (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was added. The resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under continuous stirring and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.27<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) in methanol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for additional 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (4.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the compound were grown by slow evaporation at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (45%). elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complex {(VO2)2(L1H-1)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n (1)

To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0mmol, 0.15g) in methanol (10mL) tromethamine (1.0mmol, 0.12g) was added. The resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2h at 90°C under continuous stirring and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C5H7O2)2] (1.0mmol, 0.27g) in methanol (10mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for additional 2h at 90°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (4.0mmol, 0.16g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the compound were grown by slow evaporation at 4°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.18g (45%). Calcd for 1, {[(VO2)2(L1H-1)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n (1). (V2C26H38N2Na2O16, Mr 782.44): V, 13.02; C, 39.91; H, 4.90; N 3.58. Found: V, 12.99; C, 39.88; H, 4.83; N 3.44.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0220">X-ray crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">X-ray quality crystals of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were grown from alcoholic solutions as stated above. A crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (0.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.29<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm) was taken from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>113<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with SHELXL-97 . elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determination

X-ray quality crystals of compounds 1-3 were grown from alcoholic solutions as stated above. A crystal of 1 (0.04×0.07×0.29mm) was taken from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to -113°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELXL-97 . Further experimental crystallographic details for 1: 2θ max =130°; reflections collected/unique/used, 27,751/5463 [Rint =0.0867]/5463; 508 parameters refined; (Δ/ σ)max =0.004; (Δρ)max /(Δρ)min =1.092/-0.898 e/Å3; R/Rw (for all data), 0.0958/0.2195. All hydrogen atoms were located by difference maps and were refined isotropically or were introduced at calculated positions as riding on bonded atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Plots of the structure were drawn using the Diamond 3 program package .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with dimensions 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and 0.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.52<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were taken from the mother liquor and mounted at room temperature on a Bruker Kappa APEX2 diffractometer equipped with a triumph monochromator using Mo Kα radiation. Unit cell dimensions were determined and refined by using the angular settings of at least 100 high intensity reflections (><ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>10 σ(I)) in the range of 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2θ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>40°. Intensity data were recorded using ϕ and ω scans. All crystals presented no decay during data collection. The frames collected for each crystal were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package , using a narrow-frame algorithm. Data were corrected for absorption using the numerical method (SADABS) based on crystal dimensions . All structures were solved using the SUPERFLIP package , incorporated in Crystals. Data refinement (full-matrix least-squares methods on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) and all subsequent calculations were carried out using the Crystals version 14.40b program package . All non-disordered non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. For the disordered non-hydrogen atoms, occupancy factors were first determined when refined with fixed isotropic displacements. Finally, all of them were isotropically refined with fixed occupancy factors. Hydrogen atoms were located by difference maps at their expected positions and refined using soft constraints. By the end of the refinement, they were positioned geometrically using riding constraints to bonded atoms. Illustrations with 50% ellipsoids probability were drawn by CAMERON .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Crystals of 2-3 with dimensions 0.25×0.36×0.57mm (2) and 0.13×0.16×0.52mm (3) were taken from the mother liquor and mounted at room temperature on a Bruker Kappa APEX2 diffractometer equipped with a triumph monochromator using Mo Kα radiation. Unit cell dimensions were determined and refined by using the angular settings of at least 100 high intensity reflections (>10 σ(I)) in the range of 15<2θ<40°. Intensity data were recorded using ϕ and ω scans. All crystals presented no decay during data collection. The frames collected for each crystal were integrated with the Bruker SAINT software package , using a narrow-frame algorithm. Data were corrected for absorption using the numerical method (SADABS) based on crystal dimensions . All structures were solved using the SUPERFLIP package , incorporated in Crystals. Data refinement (full-matrix least-squares methods on F2) and all subsequent calculations were carried out using the Crystals version 14.40b program package . All non-disordered non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. For the disordered non-hydrogen atoms, occupancy factors were first determined when refined with fixed isotropic displacements. Finally, all of them were isotropically refined with fixed occupancy factors. Hydrogen atoms were located by difference maps at their expected positions and refined using soft constraints. By the end of the refinement, they were positioned geometrically using riding constraints to bonded atoms. Illustrations with 50% ellipsoids probability were drawn by CAMERON .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0045">Cell cultures and biological studies</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0050">Cell culture</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">3T3-L1 fibroblasts were cultured in 75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> cell culture flasks under 5% CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and standard humidity in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium DMEM (Gibco), supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin–streptomycin.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell cultures and biological studies

Cell culture

3T3-L1 fibroblasts were cultured in 75cm2 cell culture flasks under 5% CO2 at 37°C and standard humidity in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium DMEM (Gibco), supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin-streptomycin.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0055">Induction of adipogenesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">3T3-L1 cells were differentiated into mature adipocytes according to a standard differentiation protocol . Cells were allowed to reach 70% confluency and two days later were treated with 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM 3-isobutyl-1-methylxanthine (Sigma), 1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ dexamethazone (Sigma) and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ng/mL of insulin (or variable concentrations of the title vanadium compounds) in DMEM. The experiments were conducted on the 8th day of the differentiation process.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Induction of adipogenesis

3T3-L1 cells were differentiated into mature adipocytes according to a standard differentiation protocol . Cells were allowed to reach 70% confluency and two days later were treated with 0.5mM 3-isobutyl-1-methylxanthine (Sigma), 1.0μΜ dexamethazone (Sigma) and 10ng/mL of insulin (or variable concentrations of the title vanadium compounds) in DMEM. The experiments were conducted on the 8th day of the differentiation process.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0060">Cell viability assay</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">In order to assess cytotoxicity effects of the newly synthesized vanadium compounds, 3T3-L1 (pre-adipocytes) and mature adipocytes differentiated with insulin, as mentioned above, were allowed to grow in 96-multi-well plates (2500 cells/well), and were incubated with freshly prepared solutions of the title vanadium compounds for 24 and 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in DMEM. Cell survival was evaluated through a luminescence cell viability assay (Cell titer Glo, Promega Corporation, WI, USA). The assay is based on the quantitation of ATP present, which testifies to the presence of metabolically active cells. The reagent is added to the cell culture (ratio 1:1) without removing the supernatant. The luminescence signal intensity, produced by the luciferase reaction, is determined using a Glomax 96 microplate luminometer (Promega Corporation, WI, USA).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell viability assay

In order to assess cytotoxicity effects of the newly synthesized vanadium compounds, 3T3-L1 (pre-adipocytes) and mature adipocytes differentiated with insulin, as mentioned above, were allowed to grow in 96-multi-well plates (2500 cells/well), and were incubated with freshly prepared solutions of the title vanadium compounds for 24 and 48h in DMEM. Cell survival was evaluated through a luminescence cell viability assay (Cell titer Glo, Promega Corporation, WI, USA). The assay is based on the quantitation of ATP present, which testifies to the presence of metabolically active cells. The reagent is added to the cell culture (ratio 1:1) without removing the supernatant. The luminescence signal intensity, produced by the luciferase reaction, is determined using a Glomax 96 microplate luminometer (Promega Corporation, WI, USA).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0065">Induction of adipogenesis with V(V)-compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were differentiated into mature adipocytes following a standard differentiation protocol (vide supra) . 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes (fibroblast-like) cells were treated with either 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ng/mL of insulin or selected well-defined vanadium compounds (1–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ). Freshly prepared vanadium compounds were dissolved in a DMEM medium (10% FBS, 1% penicillin/streptomycin), followed by sterile filtration. The arising solutions were used in experiments immediately. In all experiments run, the insulin group was used as a positive control. A control group with no treated cells (without insulin or vanadium compounds) was also included. On the 8th day of the differentiation process, cell differentiation was assessed with oil red O staining and Real-Time PCR for relative expression of GLUT 4. All tests were carried out in no less than triplicate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Induction of adipogenesis with V(V)-compounds

3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were differentiated into mature adipocytes following a standard differentiation protocol (vide supra) . 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes (fibroblast-like) cells were treated with either 10ng/mL of insulin or selected well-defined vanadium compounds (1-20μΜ). Freshly prepared vanadium compounds were dissolved in a DMEM medium (10% FBS, 1% penicillin/streptomycin), followed by sterile filtration. The arising solutions were used in experiments immediately. In all experiments run, the insulin group was used as a positive control. A control group with no treated cells (without insulin or vanadium compounds) was also included. On the 8th day of the differentiation process, cell differentiation was assessed with oil red O staining and Real-Time PCR for relative expression of GLUT 4. All tests were carried out in no less than triplicate.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0070">Real-time PCR (RT-PCR)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Total RNA was extracted from the cells on the 8th day of the differentiation protocol, using the TRIzol reagent (Life Science, Chemilab). Synthesis of cDNA was performed with the iScript cDNA synthesis kit (BioRad), according to the manufacturer instructions. RT-PCR was run using the QuantiTect SYBR Green PCR kit and reagents (Qiagen) with the Rotor Gene Q (Qiagen).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Real-time PCR (RT-PCR)

Total RNA was extracted from the cells on the 8th day of the differentiation protocol, using the TRIzol reagent (Life Science, Chemilab). Synthesis of cDNA was performed with the iScript cDNA synthesis kit (BioRad), according to the manufacturer instructions. RT-PCR was run using the QuantiTect SYBR Green PCR kit and reagents (Qiagen) with the Rotor Gene Q (Qiagen).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0075">Cell migration</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The motility of 3T3-L1 fibroblast-like cells was evaluated by an <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> scratch assay. For this assay, the cells were seeded in 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm cell culture dishes in DMEM. After having achieved confluency (70–80%), a scratch in the monolayer over the total diameter of each culture dish was made using a sterile pipette tip and cells were allowed to grow in the culture medium in the presence of a final concentration of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of the different vanadium complexes. The cells were visualized using an Axio Observer Z1 microscope, with a 10<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>× phase contrast water immersion objective (Carl Zeiss, GmbH Lena, Germany). Images were captured, using an AxioCam Hc camera, at two distinct time points 24 and 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h after the scratch has been made.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell migration

The motility of 3T3-L1 fibroblast-like cells was evaluated by an in vitro scratch assay. For this assay, the cells were seeded in 35mm cell culture dishes in DMEM. After having achieved confluency (70-80%), a scratch in the monolayer over the total diameter of each culture dish was made using a sterile pipette tip and cells were allowed to grow in the culture medium in the presence of a final concentration of 20μΜ of the different vanadium complexes. The cells were visualized using an Axio Observer Z1 microscope, with a 10× phase contrast water immersion objective (Carl Zeiss, GmbH Lena, Germany). Images were captured, using an AxioCam Hc camera, at two distinct time points 24 and 48h after the scratch has been made.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0080">Statistical analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The data were presented as average and standard error mean (SEM) values of triplicate sets of independent measurements. The mean survival rates and SEMs were calculated for each group. Absolute survival rates were calculated for each control group and one way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed for all pair comparisons, followed by post hoc analyses (Tukey), and Dunnet in the case of RT-PCR experiments. Degrees of significance were assessed by three different rating values: *p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05 (significant), **p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.01 (highly significant) and ***p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.001 (extremely significant) or non-significant (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Statistical analysis

The data were presented as average and standard error mean (SEM) values of triplicate sets of independent measurements. The mean survival rates and SEMs were calculated for each group. Absolute survival rates were calculated for each control group and one way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed for all pair comparisons, followed by post hoc analyses (Tukey), and Dunnet in the case of RT-PCR experiments. Degrees of significance were assessed by three different rating values: *p<0.05 (significant), **p<0.01 (highly significant) and ***p<0.001 (extremely significant) or non-significant (p>0.05).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0085">Results</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0225">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The synthetic exploration of the binary V(V)-Schiff base systems in this work followed carefully designed approaches. The employed ligands L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H–L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H were assembled <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> through Schiff base condensation reactions, involving o-vanillin and tromethamine (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H), 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H), and ethanolamine (L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H), in the course of the vanadium complex synthesis outlined below. In this regard, the {[(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) material was synthesized in a facile fashion from simple reagents in methanolic solution. In a typical reaction, [VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] reacted with the in situ assembled Schiff base L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H using methanol as a solvent, in the presence of sodium hydroxide. The overall stoichiometric reaction leading to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown schematically below:<ce:display>
<ce:formula id="fo0005">
<ce:chem>4n VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4n C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4n NaOH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4n CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⟶<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2{[(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8n C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2n H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:chem>
</ce:formula>
</ce:display>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis

The synthetic exploration of the binary V(V)-Schiff base systems in this work followed carefully designed approaches. The employed ligands L1H-L3H were assembled in situ through Schiff base condensation reactions, involving o-vanillin and tromethamine (L1H), 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (L2H), and ethanolamine (L3H), in the course of the vanadium complex synthesis outlined below. In this regard, the {[(VO2)2(L1H-1)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n (1) material was synthesized in a facile fashion from simple reagents in methanolic solution. In a typical reaction, [VO(C5H7O2)2] reacted with the in situ assembled Schiff base L1H using methanol as a solvent, in the presence of sodium hydroxide. The overall stoichiometric reaction leading to 1 is shown schematically below:  4n VO(C5H7O2)2 +4n C12H17NO5 +4n NaOH+4n CH3OH+n O2 ⟶2{[(VO2)2(C12H15NO5)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n +8n C5H8O2 +2n H2O.

The stoichiometric reaction leading to the formation of {[(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)]Na(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH)}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is shown below:<ce:display>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4n C<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2n H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:chem>
</ce:formula>
</ce:display>
