elements.content: <ce:para id="p0165" view="all">All reaction mixtures were left to evaporate slowly. Yellow crystalline materials emerged in all three reactions described above, the analytical composition of which was consistent with the formulations in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively (vide supra). Positive identification of the crystalline products was achieved by FT-IR spectroscopic methods and X-ray crystallographic determination for isolated single crystals from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. All the compounds are stable in the crystalline form, in the air, for fairly long periods of time. Freshly prepared samples of all three species dissolve in water and DMSO. They are slightly soluble in alcohols (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH, i-PrOH) and insoluble in acetone, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane at room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: All reaction mixtures were left to evaporate slowly. Yellow crystalline materials emerged in all three reactions described above, the analytical composition of which was consistent with the formulations in 1, 2 and 3, respectively (vide supra). Positive identification of the crystalline products was achieved by FT-IR spectroscopic methods and X-ray crystallographic determination for isolated single crystals from 1, 2 and 3. All the compounds are stable in the crystalline form, in the air, for fairly long periods of time. Freshly prepared samples of all three species dissolve in water and DMSO. They are slightly soluble in alcohols (CH3OH, i-PrOH) and insoluble in acetone, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0090">Description of X-ray crystallographic structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0170" view="all">The X-ray crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> reveal discrete solid state lattices. The molecular structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, respectively; selected bond distances and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The molecular structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of {Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} assembly units (), which built a 2D network. The coordination geometry around the two crystallographically independent vanadium ions, V(1) and V(2), is square pyramidal and consists of two doubly bonded oxido groups (V(1)/O6,O7 and V(2)/O26,O27) and a tridentate chelate [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand, which binds vanadium through the deprotonated phenolato and terminal alkoxido O-atoms, and the imino N-atom (V(1)/O1,O5,N1 and V(2)/O21,O25,N21). The tridentate chelate [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand and one of the doubly bonded oxido groups occupy the basal plane of the square pyramid, whereas the second oxido group occupies the apical position (O7 and O26 for V(1) and V(2), respectively). The trigonality index, τ, is 0.03 and 0.02 for V(1) and V(2), respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of X-ray crystallographic structures

The X-ray crystal structures of 1, 2, and 3 reveal discrete solid state lattices. The molecular structures of 1-3 are given in  , respectively; selected bond distances and angles are listed in  . The molecular structure of 1 consists of {Na2(MeOH)2(VO2)2(L1H-1)2} assembly units (), which built a 2D network. The coordination geometry around the two crystallographically independent vanadium ions, V(1) and V(2), is square pyramidal and consists of two doubly bonded oxido groups (V(1)/O6,O7 and V(2)/O26,O27) and a tridentate chelate [L1H-1]2- ligand, which binds vanadium through the deprotonated phenolato and terminal alkoxido O-atoms, and the imino N-atom (V(1)/O1,O5,N1 and V(2)/O21,O25,N21). The tridentate chelate [L1H-1]2- ligand and one of the doubly bonded oxido groups occupy the basal plane of the square pyramid, whereas the second oxido group occupies the apical position (O7 and O26 for V(1) and V(2), respectively). The trigonality index, τ, is 0.03 and 0.02 for V(1) and V(2), respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0175" view="all">The two mononuclear [VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)] entities are not linked directly within the tetranuclear repeating unit, which is built through the two Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions bridged in various different ways. The deprotonated phenolato O-atoms of the two [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, O1 and O21, also bridge V(1) and V(2) with Na1; the latter is also bound to the methoxy O-atoms, O2 and O22, of the ligands. The doubly bonded oxido group, O6, serves as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> bridge between V(1), Na1, Na2 and Na2′ (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>z), and the corresponding oxido group O27 serves as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridge between V(2), Na1 and Na2. One of the methanol molecules (O1m) is bound to Na1 in a monodentate fashion, while the second one (O2m) bridges Na1 and Na2. The deprotonated alkoxido atom O5 also bridges atoms V(1) and Na2. Therefore, V(1) and Na1 are linked through O1 and O6, V(2) and Na1 are linked through O21 and O27, Na1 and Na2 are linked through O6, O27 and O2m, V(1) and Na2 are linked trough O5 and O6, and V(2) and Na2 are linked only through O27.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two mononuclear [VO2(L1H-1)] entities are not linked directly within the tetranuclear repeating unit, which is built through the two Na+ ions bridged in various different ways. The deprotonated phenolato O-atoms of the two [L1H-1]2- ligands, O1 and O21, also bridge V(1) and V(2) with Na1; the latter is also bound to the methoxy O-atoms, O2 and O22, of the ligands. The doubly bonded oxido group, O6, serves as a μ4 bridge between V(1), Na1, Na2 and Na2' (2-x, 2-y, -z), and the corresponding oxido group O27 serves as a μ3 bridge between V(2), Na1 and Na2. One of the methanol molecules (O1m) is bound to Na1 in a monodentate fashion, while the second one (O2m) bridges Na1 and Na2. The deprotonated alkoxido atom O5 also bridges atoms V(1) and Na2. Therefore, V(1) and Na1 are linked through O1 and O6, V(2) and Na1 are linked through O21 and O27, Na1 and Na2 are linked through O6, O27 and O2m, V(1) and Na2 are linked trough O5 and O6, and V(2) and Na2 are linked only through O27.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0180" view="all">Two centrosymmetrically related {Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} repeating units are linked through the two Na2–O6 bonds and form octanuclear entities, which constitute the actual repeating unit of the 2D network. These octanuclear entities are linked through the four Na2–O23 bonds and form the herringbone 2D network, which extends parallel to the (10ī) plane (Fig. S2).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two centrosymmetrically related {Na2(MeOH)2(VO2)2(L1H-1)2} repeating units are linked through the two Na2-O6 bonds and form octanuclear entities, which constitute the actual repeating unit of the 2D network. These octanuclear entities are linked through the four Na2-O23 bonds and form the herringbone 2D network, which extends parallel to the (10ī) plane (Fig. S2).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0185" view="all">The two [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands coordinate the metal ions in different ways (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The ligand defined by atoms O1–O5, N1 coordinates V(1), Na1 and Na2 and adopts the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>:κ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>′:κ<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>″:κ<ce:italic>N</ce:italic> mode. The ligand defined by atoms O21–O25, N21 coordinates around V(2), Na1 and Na2‴ in a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>:κ<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>′:κ<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>″:κ<ce:italic>O</ce:italic>‴:κ<ce:italic>N</ce:italic> mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two [L1H-1]2- ligands coordinate the metal ions in different ways ( ). The ligand defined by atoms O1-O5, N1 coordinates V(1), Na1 and Na2 and adopts the μ3-κ2 O:κ2 O':κO":κN mode. The ligand defined by atoms O21-O25, N21 coordinates around V(2), Na1 and Na2‴ in a μ3-κ2 O:κO':κO":κO‴:κN mode.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0190" view="all">Atom Na1 is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms; two phenolato O1 and O21, two methoxy O2 and O22, two oxido groups O6 and O27 and two methanol molecules O1m and O2m. The bond distances in the coordination sphere are in the range of 2.374(5)–2.953(4) Å. Using the continuous shape measures (CShM) approach , the coordination geometry of Na1 can be described as a triangular dodecahedron, TDD-8 (Fig. S3). Atom Na2 is coordinated to six oxygen atoms; three oxido groups O6, O6′ and O27, one methanol molecule O2m, one deprotonated terminal alkoxido O5 and one protonated alcoholato O23″. The bond distances in the coordination sphere are in the range of 2.321(4)–2.660(4) Å. The coordination geometry can be described as distorted octahedral.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Atom Na1 is coordinated to eight oxygen atoms; two phenolato O1 and O21, two methoxy O2 and O22, two oxido groups O6 and O27 and two methanol molecules O1m and O2m. The bond distances in the coordination sphere are in the range of 2.374(5)-2.953(4) Å. Using the continuous shape measures (CShM) approach , the coordination geometry of Na1 can be described as a triangular dodecahedron, TDD-8 (Fig. S3). Atom Na2 is coordinated to six oxygen atoms; three oxido groups O6, O6' and O27, one methanol molecule O2m, one deprotonated terminal alkoxido O5 and one protonated alcoholato O23". The bond distances in the coordination sphere are in the range of 2.321(4)-2.660(4) Å. The coordination geometry can be described as distorted octahedral.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0195" view="all">The protonated alcoholato groups of the two [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands and the coordinated methanol molecules participate in hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1), which can be divided in four groups: i) the intramolecular O3⋯O25 within the tetranuclear unit, ii) the intramolecular O2m⋯O5′ (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>z) within the octanuclear unit, iii) the intralayer O23⋯O26‴ (2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>z), and iv) two interlayer O4⋯O26 (−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, y, z) and O24⋯O4 (1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>y, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>z), which link the 2D networks to an overall 3D structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The protonated alcoholato groups of the two [L1H-1]2- ligands and the coordinated methanol molecules participate in hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1), which can be divided in four groups: i) the intramolecular O3⋯O25 within the tetranuclear unit, ii) the intramolecular O2m⋯O5' (2-x, 2-y, -z) within the octanuclear unit, iii) the intralayer O23⋯O26‴ (2.5-x, -0.5+y, 0.5-z), and iv) two interlayer O4⋯O26 (-1+x, y, z) and O24⋯O4 (1.5-x, -0.5+y, 0.5-z), which link the 2D networks to an overall 3D structure ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0200" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/c space group. The asymmetric unit contains two discrete complex monomeric unit assemblies (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Each one of them consists of one V(V) dioxido (VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>) unit, one sodium ion, one doubly deprotonated Schiff base ligand and one ethanol solvent molecule. The ligand exhibits a pentadentate chelate coordination capacity. Deprotonation of the Schiff base ligand occurs at the phenolic oxygen and one of the two alcoholic groups. Both parts have similar interatomic distances and angles. Each monomeric assembly of the asymmetric unit, duplicated through the center of symmetry located in the center of the parallelogram formed by two Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions and two triply-bridging dioxido oxygen atoms, gives rise to the repeating unit of the polymeric structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/c space group. The asymmetric unit contains two discrete complex monomeric unit assemblies ( ). Each one of them consists of one V(V) dioxido (VO2 +) unit, one sodium ion, one doubly deprotonated Schiff base ligand and one ethanol solvent molecule. The ligand exhibits a pentadentate chelate coordination capacity. Deprotonation of the Schiff base ligand occurs at the phenolic oxygen and one of the two alcoholic groups. Both parts have similar interatomic distances and angles. Each monomeric assembly of the asymmetric unit, duplicated through the center of symmetry located in the center of the parallelogram formed by two Na+ ions and two triply-bridging dioxido oxygen atoms, gives rise to the repeating unit of the polymeric structure.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0205" view="all">Each V(V) ion is bound to two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6 for V1, and O12 and O13 for V2), thereby forming the V(V) dioxido moiety. Vanadium is also coordinated to one deprotonated phenolic oxygen atom (O1 for V1 and O8 for V2), the imino nitrogen atom (N1 for V1 and N2 for V2) of the ligand and finally to the deprotonated oxygen (O3 for V1 and O10 for V2) of one alcoholic arm of the ligand. The five atoms coordinated to each V(V) center form a tetragonal pyramid around it. The basal plane involves the three previously mentioned atoms coming from the ligand as well as one of the oxygen of the dioxido moiety, while the second dioxido oxygen atom occupies the apical position. The dioxido oxygen atom of the basal plane is triply bridging the V(V) center of the specific monomeric assembly with the sodium atom of the same assembly, one symmetry generated neighboring sodium ion as well as the sodium ions together. The trigonality index, τ, is 0.03 for both independent complexes. The phenolic oxygen atom is also bridging the V(V) ion with the sodium ion. Finally, the protonated alcoholic oxygen is long-bridging the title vanadium assembly in the asymmetric unit with a neighboring one through the sodium ion. The finally arising lattice can be described as one consisting of a one dimensional polymeric chain parallel to the b crystallographic axis (Fig. S4-A).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each V(V) ion is bound to two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6 for V1, and O12 and O13 for V2), thereby forming the V(V) dioxido moiety. Vanadium is also coordinated to one deprotonated phenolic oxygen atom (O1 for V1 and O8 for V2), the imino nitrogen atom (N1 for V1 and N2 for V2) of the ligand and finally to the deprotonated oxygen (O3 for V1 and O10 for V2) of one alcoholic arm of the ligand. The five atoms coordinated to each V(V) center form a tetragonal pyramid around it. The basal plane involves the three previously mentioned atoms coming from the ligand as well as one of the oxygen of the dioxido moiety, while the second dioxido oxygen atom occupies the apical position. The dioxido oxygen atom of the basal plane is triply bridging the V(V) center of the specific monomeric assembly with the sodium atom of the same assembly, one symmetry generated neighboring sodium ion as well as the sodium ions together. The trigonality index, τ, is 0.03 for both independent complexes. The phenolic oxygen atom is also bridging the V(V) ion with the sodium ion. Finally, the protonated alcoholic oxygen is long-bridging the title vanadium assembly in the asymmetric unit with a neighboring one through the sodium ion. The finally arising lattice can be described as one consisting of a one dimensional polymeric chain parallel to the b crystallographic axis (Fig. S4-A).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0210" view="all">Each sodium ion has six oxygen atoms in close proximity: two bridging oxygen atoms, one from the monomeric assembly and one from a neighboring asymmetric unit coming from V(V) dioxido moieties, one bridging oxygen from the deprotonated phenolic group, one methoxy oxygen atom from the Schiff base ligand, one oxygen from a solvent ethanol molecule and finally one bridging oxygen from the alcoholic group of a neighboring ligand. The geometry around each sodium ion can be described as highly distorted trigonal prismatic.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each sodium ion has six oxygen atoms in close proximity: two bridging oxygen atoms, one from the monomeric assembly and one from a neighboring asymmetric unit coming from V(V) dioxido moieties, one bridging oxygen from the deprotonated phenolic group, one methoxy oxygen atom from the Schiff base ligand, one oxygen from a solvent ethanol molecule and finally one bridging oxygen from the alcoholic group of a neighboring ligand. The geometry around each sodium ion can be described as highly distorted trigonal prismatic.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0215" view="all">Hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1) hold the coordinated ethanol molecules in close contact (Fig. S4-B). They arise between a) alcoholic moieties of the vanadium monomeric assembly with the alkoxido oxygen from a ligand of the symmetry-generated assembly, and b) the alcoholic oxygen with the apical dioxido oxygen atom. No interactions have been detected between chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1) hold the coordinated ethanol molecules in close contact (Fig. S4-B). They arise between a) alcoholic moieties of the vanadium monomeric assembly with the alkoxido oxygen from a ligand of the symmetry-generated assembly, and b) the alcoholic oxygen with the apical dioxido oxygen atom. No interactions have been detected between chains.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0220" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pna2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> space group. The asymmetric unit contains one complex monomeric assembly. It contains one V(V) dioxido unit (VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>), one sodium ion, one doubly deprotonated Schiff base ligand and one water molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The monomeric part, upon duplication through a two-fold screw axis in the direction [0, 0, 1] at 0, 0, z with a screw component [0, 0, 1/2] in the mid-distance of two neighboring sodium ions, generates the repeating unit of the polymeric structure. The doubly deprotonated ligand exhibits a tetradentate coordination capacity through the imino nitrogen N10 and the alkoxido oxygen O3 as well as the phenolato O1 and methoxy O2 oxygen atoms. The V(V) ion is bound to two oxygen atoms to form the dioxido VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> moiety and coordinated to the imino nitrogen as well as the phenolic oxygen atoms. The geometry around each V(V) center can be described as tetragonal pyramidal with one of the oxygen atoms of the dioxido moiety occupying the apical position. The trigonality index, τ, is 0.12.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pna21 space group. The asymmetric unit contains one complex monomeric assembly. It contains one V(V) dioxido unit (VO2 +), one sodium ion, one doubly deprotonated Schiff base ligand and one water molecule ( ). The monomeric part, upon duplication through a two-fold screw axis in the direction [0, 0, 1] at 0, 0, z with a screw component [0, 0, 1/2] in the mid-distance of two neighboring sodium ions, generates the repeating unit of the polymeric structure. The doubly deprotonated ligand exhibits a tetradentate coordination capacity through the imino nitrogen N10 and the alkoxido oxygen O3 as well as the phenolato O1 and methoxy O2 oxygen atoms. The V(V) ion is bound to two oxygen atoms to form the dioxido VO2 + moiety and coordinated to the imino nitrogen as well as the phenolic oxygen atoms. The geometry around each V(V) center can be described as tetragonal pyramidal with one of the oxygen atoms of the dioxido moiety occupying the apical position. The trigonality index, τ, is 0.12.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0225" view="all">The phenolic oxygen atom is bridging the V(V) center and the sodium ion of the title monomeric assembly. The basal plane dioxido oxygen atom is triply bridging the V(V) and two sodium ions coming from the monomeric assembly and a symmetry-generated neighboring monomer. A water molecule is bridging contiguous sodium ions, forming a final 1D polymeric structure, with chains parallel to the c crystallographic axis (Fig. S5-A).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The phenolic oxygen atom is bridging the V(V) center and the sodium ion of the title monomeric assembly. The basal plane dioxido oxygen atom is triply bridging the V(V) and two sodium ions coming from the monomeric assembly and a symmetry-generated neighboring monomer. A water molecule is bridging contiguous sodium ions, forming a final 1D polymeric structure, with chains parallel to the c crystallographic axis (Fig. S5-A).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0230" view="all">Each sodium ion exhibits a coordination number six, with the coordinated oxygen atoms formulating a highly distorted trigonal prismatic geometry. The coordinated atoms are one methoxy oxygen from the Schiff ligand, one of the dioxido oxygen atoms of the same assembly and its symmetry generated counterpart, one bridging water oxygen and its symmetry generated congener as well as one phenolic oxygen from the same assembly.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Each sodium ion exhibits a coordination number six, with the coordinated oxygen atoms formulating a highly distorted trigonal prismatic geometry. The coordinated atoms are one methoxy oxygen from the Schiff ligand, one of the dioxido oxygen atoms of the same assembly and its symmetry generated counterpart, one bridging water oxygen and its symmetry generated congener as well as one phenolic oxygen from the same assembly.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0235" view="all">Hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1) arise from the bridging water molecule to the alkoxido oxygen atom of the ligand as well as both dioxido oxygen atoms (Fig. S5-B). No interaction between chains has been found.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table S1) arise from the bridging water molecule to the alkoxido oxygen atom of the ligand as well as both dioxido oxygen atoms (Fig. S5-B). No interaction between chains has been found.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0230">FT-IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0240" view="all">The infrared spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show active ν(OH) and ν(C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N) vibrations at 3352–3413 and 1620–1629<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, respectively, with the binding of the imine nitrogen revealed by lowering of the resonance frequency (13–15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>). Specifically, ν(OH) and ν(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) emerged at 3413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>n</ce:sup> and 1620<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 3352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 1629<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 3413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 1620<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The characteristic ν(V<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O) stretch appears as a medium-strong band at 958<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 983<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 958<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively . All data were further attested to by the X-ray crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR spectroscopy

The infrared spectra of 1-3 show active ν(OH) and ν(C=N) vibrations at 3352-3413 and 1620-1629cm-1, respectively, with the binding of the imine nitrogen revealed by lowering of the resonance frequency (13-15cm-1). Specifically, ν(OH) and ν(CN) emerged at 3413cm-n and 1620cm-1 for 1, 3352cm-1 and 1629cm-1 for 2, and 3413cm-1 and 1620cm-1 for 3. The characteristic ν(VO) stretch appears as a medium-strong band at 958cm-1 for 1, 983cm-1 for 2, and 958cm-1 for 3, respectively . All data were further attested to by the X-ray crystal structures of 1-3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0235">UV–vis spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0245" view="all">The electronic spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were recorded in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Fig. S6). In all cases, a very strong absorption band in the range 450 and 530<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm may be assigned to a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition, originating from the p(π) orbital of the phenolate oxygen to the unfilled d(π*) orbitals of the metal . Two less intense bands, in the range of 230–380<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are considered to arise from π–π* transitions in the aromatic ring, and from π–π* and n–π* transitions of the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N moiety .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
UV-vis spectroscopy

The electronic spectra of 1-3 were recorded in H2O (Fig. S6). In all cases, a very strong absorption band in the range 450 and 530nm may be assigned to a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition, originating from the p(π) orbital of the phenolate oxygen to the unfilled d(π*) orbitals of the metal . Two less intense bands, in the range of 230-380nm are considered to arise from π-π* transitions in the aromatic ring, and from π-π* and n-π* transitions of the CN moiety .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0095">Solid-state NMR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0250" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C CPMAS spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (A-1<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>) exhibits resonances between a) 50.6 and 73.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 112.3 and 125.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range 148.5–153.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 163.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound to V(V). The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C CPMAS spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (A-2) exhibits resonances between a) 54.1 and 67.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 114.5 and 125.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 147.7–154.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 164.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound to V(V). The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C CPMAS spectrum of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (A-3) exhibits resonances between a) 55.7 and 74.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methylene carbons, and b) 114.1 and 124.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 147.4–151.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 164.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm stands in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound into the V(V) coordination sphere. All of the above observations were consistent with X-ray crystallographic results.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solid-state NMR spectroscopy

The 13C CPMAS spectrum of 1 (A-1) exhibits resonances between a) 50.6 and 73.7ppm attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 112.3 and 125.1ppm and in the range 148.5-153.9ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 163.8ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L1H-1]2- ligand bound to V(V). The 13C CPMAS spectrum of 2 (A-2) exhibits resonances between a) 54.1 and 67.1ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 114.5 and 125.8ppm and in the range of 147.7-154.3ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 164.2ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L2H-1]2- ligand bound to V(V). The 13C CPMAS spectrum of 3 (A-3) exhibits resonances between a) 55.7 and 74.9ppm, attributed to methylene carbons, and b) 114.1 and 124.1ppm and in the range of 147.4-151.9ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 164.1ppm stands in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L3H-1]2- ligand bound into the V(V) coordination sphere. All of the above observations were consistent with X-ray crystallographic results.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0255" view="all">
<ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V has a spin of 7/2, a fact that has been reportedly exploited to gain knowledge on structural features of V(V) compounds . To this end, the <ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V MAS NMR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained, with NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> as the reference (−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>514.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm). Positive chemical shift values (δ) are taken to correspond to lower shielding in comparison to the reference. The spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit resonances in a broad range (−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>300 to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm), with the main signals bearing multiple spinning sidebands due to both quadrupolar coupling and chemical shift anisotropy. The identity of the central resonances was confirmed by running experiments with different spinning frequencies. The resonance, the chemical shift of which did not change with frequency, was the one attributed to the main resonance. The spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one central resonance at −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>535.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (A<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>), with the spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> showing one central resonance at −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>541.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (B) and that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> displaying one central resonance at −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>536.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm (C). It should be noted that assignments of NMR shifts to different coordination numbers of V(V) compounds are not straightforward . On the basis of past reports on several known compounds , various patterns had been observed, earmarking specific regions in the <ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V spectrum for five, six, and seven coordinate V(V) ions. To this end <ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V solid-state NMR is very sensitive even to small angle changes in the coordination geometry around a V(V) center. Consistent with the above information, five-coordinate V(V) compounds exhibit resonances in the range of −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>350 and −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm. The <ce:sup loc="pre">51</ce:sup>V resonances observed for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are, therefore, consistent with the crystallographically determined five-coordinate centers in the respective compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 51V has a spin of 7/2, a fact that has been reportedly exploited to gain knowledge on structural features of V(V) compounds . To this end, the 51V MAS NMR spectra of 1-3 were obtained, with NaVO3 as the reference (-514.4ppm). Positive chemical shift values (δ) are taken to correspond to lower shielding in comparison to the reference. The spectra of 1-3 exhibit resonances in a broad range (-300 to -1000ppm), with the main signals bearing multiple spinning sidebands due to both quadrupolar coupling and chemical shift anisotropy. The identity of the central resonances was confirmed by running experiments with different spinning frequencies. The resonance, the chemical shift of which did not change with frequency, was the one attributed to the main resonance. The spectrum of 1 exhibits one central resonance at -535.7ppm (A), with the spectrum of 2 showing one central resonance at -541.3ppm (B) and that of 3 displaying one central resonance at -536.5ppm (C). It should be noted that assignments of NMR shifts to different coordination numbers of V(V) compounds are not straightforward . On the basis of past reports on several known compounds , various patterns had been observed, earmarking specific regions in the 51V spectrum for five, six, and seven coordinate V(V) ions. To this end 51V solid-state NMR is very sensitive even to small angle changes in the coordination geometry around a V(V) center. Consistent with the above information, five-coordinate V(V) compounds exhibit resonances in the range of -350 and -500ppm. The 51V resonances observed for 1-3 are, therefore, consistent with the crystallographically determined five-coordinate centers in the respective compounds.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0240">Solution NMR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0260" view="all">The solution <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C-NMR spectrum of <ce:bold>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H</ce:bold> was recorded in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Fig. S7-A). The spectrum of <ce:bold>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H</ce:bold> exhibits resonances between a) 53.8 and 65.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 114.9 and 125.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 152.3–165.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 167.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon. The solution <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were measured in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (). The spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (B-1) exhibits resonances between a) 55.9 and 72.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 118.3 and 125.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 148.1–154.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 165.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound into the V(V) coordination sphere. The <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (B-2) exhibits resonances between a) 53.1 and 73.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 116.6 and 125.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 148.6–158.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 166.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound to the V(V) center. The corresponding <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C spectrum of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (B-3) exhibits resonances between a) 53.8 and 67.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 116.3 and 125.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and in the range of 148.9–155.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 168.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm stands in line with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound to V(V). These observations were subsequently confirmed by X-ray crystallography. The resonance shift was ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> downfield and was comparable to that observed in the CPMAS <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR solid-state spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solution NMR spectroscopy

The solution 13C-NMR spectrum of L2H was recorded in D2O (Fig. S7-A). The spectrum of L2H exhibits resonances between a) 53.8 and 65.9ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 114.9 and 125.3ppm and in the range of 152.3-165.1ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 167.7ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon. The solution 13C NMR spectra of complexes 1-3 were measured in D2O (). The spectrum of 1 (B-1) exhibits resonances between a) 55.9 and 72.8ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 118.3 and 125.9ppm and in the range of 148.1-154.1ppm, attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 165.6ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L1H-1]2- ligand bound into the V(V) coordination sphere. The 13C spectrum of 2 (B-2) exhibits resonances between a) 53.1 and 73.4ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 116.6 and 125.4ppm and in the range of 148.6-158.2ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 166.9ppm is in agreement with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L2H-1]2- ligand bound to the V(V) center. The corresponding 13C spectrum of 3 (B-3) exhibits resonances between a) 53.8 and 67.7ppm, attributed to methyl and methylene carbons, and b) 116.3 and 125.9ppm and in the range of 148.9-155.2ppm attributed to the presence of aromatic carbons. A resonance at 168.6ppm stands in line with the presence of the azomethine carbon of the [L3H-1]2- ligand bound to V(V). These observations were subsequently confirmed by X-ray crystallography. The resonance shift was ~2.0ppm for 1-3 downfield and was comparable to that observed in the CPMAS 13C NMR solid-state spectrum of 1-3.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0265" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra of L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O show several resonances (Fig. S7-B). The resonances between 3.2 and 3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm are attributed to the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH moieties, with the resonance at 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm being attributed to the –N–CH moiety. The resonance at 3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the methoxy group –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> of the L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H ligand. The third group of signals between 6.5 and 7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is ascribed to the proton of the –CH<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group of L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectra of L2H in D2O show several resonances (Fig. S7-B). The resonances between 3.2 and 3.6ppm are attributed to the -CH2OH moieties, with the resonance at 3.7ppm being attributed to the -N-CH moiety. The resonance at 3.8ppm is attributed to the methoxy group -OCH3 of the L2H ligand. The third group of signals between 6.5 and 7.1ppm is attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.3ppm is ascribed to the proton of the -CHN group of L2H.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0270" view="all">The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in D<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O showed several resonances. Resonances in the range of 6.4–7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm are attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the –CH<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group of the [L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand bound to V(V). The spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S8-B) exhibits resonances in the range of 1.4–2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm consistent with the presence of methyl protons in lattice ethanol. The resonance at a) 2.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the presence of the –OH group in ethanol and b) 3.24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the presence of the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group in ethanol. The resonances in the range of 3.4–3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm are attributed to the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH groups. The resonance at a) 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm could be attributed to –N–CH group, b) 3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the methoxy group –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and c) 4.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm could be attributed to the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group. The resonances in the range of 6.3–7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The signal at 8.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the –CH<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group in [L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> bound to V(V). The spectrum of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (Fig. S8-C) shows a resonance at 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm consistent with the presence of the –N–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group. The resonance at a) 3.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm is attributed to the methoxy group –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and b) 4.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm could be attributed to the –CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group. The signals in the range of 6.4–7.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be ascribed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the –CH<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N group in [L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> bound to V(V).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR spectra of 1-3 in D2O showed several resonances. The spectrum of 1 (Fig. S8-A) shows resonances in the range of 3.2-3.4ppm attributed to the presence of methanol. The resonance at a) 3.7ppm is attributed to the first -CH2OH group, b) 3.78ppm is attributed to the methoxy group -OCH3 protons, c) 3.83ppm could be attributed to the -CH2O- group, and d) 4.10ppm is attributed to the second protonated -CH2OH group. Resonances in the range of 6.4-7.1ppm are attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.6ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the -CHN group of the [L1H-1]2- ligand bound to V(V). The spectrum of 2 (Fig. S8-B) exhibits resonances in the range of 1.4-2.0ppm consistent with the presence of methyl protons in lattice ethanol. The resonance at a) 2.9ppm is attributed to the presence of the -OH group in ethanol and b) 3.24ppm is attributed to the presence of the -CH2 group in ethanol. The resonances in the range of 3.4-3.6ppm are attributed to the -CH2OH groups. The resonance at a) 3.7ppm could be attributed to -N-CH group, b) 3.8ppm is attributed to the methoxy group -OCH3, and c) 4.1ppm could be attributed to the -CH2O- group. The resonances in the range of 6.3-7.1ppm can be attributed to the presence of aromatic protons. The signal at 8.7ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the -CHN group in [L2H-1]2- bound to V(V). The spectrum of 3 (Fig. S8-C) shows a resonance at 3.7ppm consistent with the presence of the -N-CH2 group. The resonance at a) 3.7ppm is attributed to the methoxy group -OCH3, and b) 4.1ppm could be attributed to the -CH2O- group. The signals in the range of 6.4-7.1ppm can be ascribed to the presence of aromatic protons. The resonance at 8.6ppm can be ascribed to the proton of the -CHN group in [L3H-1]2- bound to V(V).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0245">Thermal studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0275" view="all">The thermal decomposition of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was studied by TGA under an atmosphere of oxygen (Fig. S9). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is thermally stable up to 97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 601<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule (Fig. S9-A). No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further. A plateau in the decomposition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is reached at 601<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with no further loss up to 850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal studies

The thermal decomposition of complexes 1-3 was studied by TGA under an atmosphere of oxygen (Fig. S9). Compound 1 is thermally stable up to 97°C. Between 97°C and 601°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule (Fig. S9-A). No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further. A plateau in the decomposition of 1 is reached at 601°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0280" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is thermally stable up to 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 491<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-B). A plateau in the decomposition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is reached at 491<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with no further loss up to 850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
