elements.content: <ce:para id="p0290" view="all">Examination of the residue(s) by SEM showed the presence of vanadium and sodium with a ratio of 1:1, in line with the a) atomic ratio of V:Na present in the original molecular formulae, and b) presence of oxides ordinarily obtained under oxidative conditions, and consistent with previously reported results of thermogravimetric analysis on vanadium and sodium-containing species .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Examination of the residue(s) by SEM showed the presence of vanadium and sodium with a ratio of 1:1, in line with the a) atomic ratio of V:Na present in the original molecular formulae, and b) presence of oxides ordinarily obtained under oxidative conditions, and consistent with previously reported results of thermogravimetric analysis on vanadium and sodium-containing species .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0100">Cytotoxicity results</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0105">V(V) cell toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0295" view="all">In an effort to examine whether V(V) ions (non-complexed inorganic vanadium) affect cell survival, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with 1, 10, 100, or 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of KVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (A<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). The results show that V(V) affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Specifically, reduction in cell survival is not affected at low concentrations (1, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) compared to the control, whereas reduction in cell survival amounts to 40% at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ and almost 50% at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control, exhibiting full reduction of cell survival under the employed experimental conditions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cytotoxicity results

V(V) cell toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

In an effort to examine whether V(V) ions (non-complexed inorganic vanadium) affect cell survival, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with 1, 10, 100, or 200μΜ of KVO3 for 24h (A). The results show that V(V) affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Specifically, reduction in cell survival is not affected at low concentrations (1, 10μΜ) compared to the control, whereas reduction in cell survival amounts to 40% at 100μΜ and almost 50% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control, exhibiting full reduction of cell survival under the employed experimental conditions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0110">Ligand toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0300" view="all">To investigate the cytotoxic potential of the organic ligands–substrates L<ce:inf loc="post">i</ce:inf>H (i<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1–3) on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, the cells were treated with 1, 10, 100, 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H and L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H, respectively, for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h ( B-1 through B-3). The results show that L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Ιn particular, L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H causes reduction in cell survival amounting to 28% at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, 35% at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, 70% at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ and ><ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>90% at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Ligand L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H reduces cell survival only at the highest concentration (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ). Ligand L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H is not cytotoxic at all concentrations tested (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Ligand toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

To investigate the cytotoxic potential of the organic ligands-substrates LiH (i=1-3) on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, the cells were treated with 1, 10, 100, 200μΜ of L1H, L2H and L3H, respectively, for 24h ( B-1 through B-3). The results show that L3H affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Ιn particular, L3H causes reduction in cell survival amounting to 28% at 1μΜ, 35% at 10μΜ, 70% at 100μΜ and >90% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Ligand L1H reduces cell survival only at the highest concentration (200μΜ). Ligand L2H is not cytotoxic at all concentrations tested (p>0.05).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0115">V(V) compound toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0305" view="all">To assess cell toxicity of the title compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with various concentrations (1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (A<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>). The results show that none of the tested compounds are toxic even at the highest concentrations employed (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05) compared to the control. Noteworthy is the fact that <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> appears to be non-toxic although its ligand L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H reduces cell survival at the same concentration range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
V(V) compound toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes for 24h

To assess cell toxicity of the title compounds 1-3, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with various concentrations (1-100μΜ) of 1-3 for 24h (A). The results show that none of the tested compounds are toxic even at the highest concentrations employed (100μΜ) (p>0.05) compared to the control. Noteworthy is the fact that 3 appears to be non-toxic although its ligand L3H reduces cell survival at the same concentration range.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0120">V(V) compound toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0310" view="all">During the induction of the differentiation process, the cells are exposed to V(V) compounds for more than 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Consequently, the potential cytotoxic effects of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were investigated at various concentrations (1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. B shows that all three vanadium materials appear to be non-toxic compared to the control for concentrations ranging from 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ to 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). It appears, therefore, that all compounds tested could further be employed in the induction of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocyte differentiation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
V(V) compound toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes for 48h

During the induction of the differentiation process, the cells are exposed to V(V) compounds for more than 24h. Consequently, the potential cytotoxic effects of 1, 2 and 3 were investigated at various concentrations (1-50μΜ) for 48h. B shows that all three vanadium materials appear to be non-toxic compared to the control for concentrations ranging from 1μΜ to 50μΜ (p>0.05). It appears, therefore, that all compounds tested could further be employed in the induction of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocyte differentiation.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0125">V(V) compound toxicity in differentiated 3T3-L1 for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0315" view="all">To examine whether V(V)-compounds affect cell survival in differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes, cells were treated with various concentrations (1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor> shows that a) <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is non-toxic at all concentrations studied (1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM), and b) both <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> appear to be non-toxic in the concentration range of 1–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
V(V) compound toxicity in differentiated 3T3-L1 for 48h

To examine whether V(V)-compounds affect cell survival in differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes, cells were treated with various concentrations (1-50μΜ) of 1, 2 and 3 for 48h.   shows that a) 1 is non-toxic at all concentrations studied (1-50μM), and b) both 2 and 3 appear to be non-toxic in the concentration range of 1-20μΜ (p>0.05).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0130">Cell migration assay</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0320" view="all">To assess the inhibition of cell migration potential of the vanadium compounds on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, a scratch assay was performed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>). The cells were treated with 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of each compound for 24 and 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The migration capacity of cells grown in the presence of DMEM only was considered as control. In the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the cells showed limited migration at the concentration tested. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> appeared to have no effect on the physiological cell motility, in congruence with the behavior of the control. The observed behavior of the cells for the 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h experiments was very similar to that for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (data not shown).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell migration assay

To assess the inhibition of cell migration potential of the vanadium compounds on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, a scratch assay was performed ( ). The cells were treated with 20μΜ of each compound for 24 and 48h. The migration capacity of cells grown in the presence of DMEM only was considered as control. In the case of 2 and 3, the cells showed limited migration at the concentration tested. Compound 1 appeared to have no effect on the physiological cell motility, in congruence with the behavior of the control. The observed behavior of the cells for the 48h experiments was very similar to that for 24h (data not shown).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0135">V(V)-induced differentiation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0325" view="all">In an effort to investigate the insulin-mimetic activity, the title complexes were used to induce differentiation of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes according to standard protocol. All employed compounds induced differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes as assessed by oil Red O staining (1–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ). Differentiation was clearly evident at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM. The maximal effect was observed at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, when cells were treated with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> appears to exert its maximal effect at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ. The effect of the three compounds tested was comparable to the differentiation effect induced by insulin (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ng/mL) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition, all three compounds were used at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ in combination with insulin, in an effort to probe potential synergistic interactions involving insulin and the title vanadium compounds. Of the three compounds, only <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showed evidence of differentiation exemplified through oil red O staining results. To further substantiate the differentiation of pre-adipocytes treated with V(V), RT-PCR was employed to assess the relative expression of GLUT 4 in mature adipocytes. To this end, differentiated mature adipocytes showed a 6.4-fold increase of GLUT 4 compared to undifferentiated pre-adipocytes (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.01), when treated with 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>). In the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there was a 10.4-fold increase when cells were treated with the same vanadium concentration. Interestingly, in the case of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the maximum effect was observed at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>11 fold). When insulin was used in the differentiation medium of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes in combination with one of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, mRNA expression grew limited in the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (compared to insulin), whereas in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the relative concentration of GLUT 4 mRNA was similar to that of insulin and the compound itself at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
V(V)-induced differentiation

In an effort to investigate the insulin-mimetic activity, the title complexes were used to induce differentiation of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes according to standard protocol. All employed compounds induced differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes as assessed by oil Red O staining (1-20μΜ). Differentiation was clearly evident at 1μM. The maximal effect was observed at 20μΜ, when cells were treated with 1 and 2. Compound 3 appears to exert its maximal effect at 1μΜ. The effect of the three compounds tested was comparable to the differentiation effect induced by insulin (10ng/mL) ( ). In addition, all three compounds were used at 20μΜ in combination with insulin, in an effort to probe potential synergistic interactions involving insulin and the title vanadium compounds. Of the three compounds, only 3 showed evidence of differentiation exemplified through oil red O staining results. To further substantiate the differentiation of pre-adipocytes treated with V(V), RT-PCR was employed to assess the relative expression of GLUT 4 in mature adipocytes. To this end, differentiated mature adipocytes showed a 6.4-fold increase of GLUT 4 compared to undifferentiated pre-adipocytes (p<0.01), when treated with 20μΜ of 1 ( ). In the case of 2, there was a 10.4-fold increase when cells were treated with the same vanadium concentration. Interestingly, in the case of 3, the maximum effect was observed at 1μΜ (~11 fold). When insulin was used in the differentiation medium of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes in combination with one of 1-3, mRNA expression grew limited in the case of 1 and 2 (compared to insulin), whereas in 3 the relative concentration of GLUT 4 mRNA was similar to that of insulin and the compound itself at 20μΜ.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0140">Discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0145">The design and synthesis of V(V)-Schiff compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0330" view="all">The biological activity profile of V(V) rests significantly on its coordination environment. The latter emerges through appropriate selection of organic substrates–ligands bound to it. In turn, the nature of the coordinated ligands, exemplified through specific chemical and structural characteristics, influences the chemical affinity toward that metal ion and likely its (bio)chemical reactivity. Careful choices in hydrophilicity–hydrophobicity, (O,N)-containing moieties capable of promoting binding to V(V), and functionalities capable of promoting V(V) chelation, collectively contribute to the ultimate vanadium coordination environment. That collective yet complex fine-tuning of vanadium guides its kinetically and/or thermodynamically driven reactivity toward molecular targets, thereby conferring specific activity at sites of interest in the cellular milieu. Consequently, such a collective profile appears to be desired for a vanadoform to emerge as an efficacious insulin-mimetic agent in Diabetes mellitus II.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The design and synthesis of V(V)-Schiff compounds

The biological activity profile of V(V) rests significantly on its coordination environment. The latter emerges through appropriate selection of organic substrates-ligands bound to it. In turn, the nature of the coordinated ligands, exemplified through specific chemical and structural characteristics, influences the chemical affinity toward that metal ion and likely its (bio)chemical reactivity. Careful choices in hydrophilicity-hydrophobicity, (O,N)-containing moieties capable of promoting binding to V(V), and functionalities capable of promoting V(V) chelation, collectively contribute to the ultimate vanadium coordination environment. That collective yet complex fine-tuning of vanadium guides its kinetically and/or thermodynamically driven reactivity toward molecular targets, thereby conferring specific activity at sites of interest in the cellular milieu. Consequently, such a collective profile appears to be desired for a vanadoform to emerge as an efficacious insulin-mimetic agent in Diabetes mellitus II.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0335" view="all">In pursuit of such appropriately configured vanadium species, the organic substrates–ligands chosen in this work to promote chemistry toward V(V) satisfy several of the above stated criteria. To this end, they aid the synthesis of binary V(V)-Schiff base materials poised to influence cellular physiology and metabolism such that fibroblast differentiation can lead toward mature adipocytes active in reducing hyperglycemia in Diabetes mellitus II. It is in this regard, that the ligands employed in the herein Schiff synthesis were selected so that a) they contain a common core exemplified by the vanillin structural motif, and b) the annotated amino alcoholic tether reflects a well-defined moiety, the structural variability of which reflects potential interaction anchors in the soluble complex vanadoforms bearing a single (L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H) up to a triple (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H) alcoholic entity. The vanillin core-based Schiff contains a well-configured cavity for V(V) binding through the phenolato and imino moieties, with the remainder of the available coordination sites potentially being taken up by two doubly bonded oxido groups and the alcoholic moieties attached to the Schiff core. The presence of the tethered alcoholic moieties also serves the purpose of providing the opportunity to the ligand, in its bound form to V(V), to seek and establish interactions (i.e. through hydrogen bonding or binding) with cellular targets, thereby facilitating V(V) reactivity exemplified through atoxicity, cell differentiation and/or insulin mimetic activity. Thus, the synthesis of the organic ligands and the ensuing binary hybrid materials is intimately linked to the potential role that they might exhibit, as bound ligands to V(V), in investigating and evaluating the biochemical reactivity of that metal ion. Synthetic implementation of that idea led to the use of a common source of [VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)] as a synthon containing acetylacetonato groups. Under appropriate reaction conditions, materials <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> emerged and were isolated in single crystalline form. In all cases, oxidation of V(IV) to V(V) takes place as a predominant process leading to the emergence of the ultimately isolated [V(V)O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>-containing complex assemblies. The physicochemical characterization of both the ligands and the corresponding materials <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> relied on elemental analysis, FT-IR, ESI-MS, NMR and X-ray crystallography, thereby providing a solid basis for their employment in the ensuing biological experiments. The species arising in solution are consistent with the dissolution of the polymeric architecture of the three materials and the rise of the mononuclear assemblies in each case.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In pursuit of such appropriately configured vanadium species, the organic substrates-ligands chosen in this work to promote chemistry toward V(V) satisfy several of the above stated criteria. To this end, they aid the synthesis of binary V(V)-Schiff base materials poised to influence cellular physiology and metabolism such that fibroblast differentiation can lead toward mature adipocytes active in reducing hyperglycemia in Diabetes mellitus II. It is in this regard, that the ligands employed in the herein Schiff synthesis were selected so that a) they contain a common core exemplified by the vanillin structural motif, and b) the annotated amino alcoholic tether reflects a well-defined moiety, the structural variability of which reflects potential interaction anchors in the soluble complex vanadoforms bearing a single (L3H) up to a triple (L1H) alcoholic entity. The vanillin core-based Schiff contains a well-configured cavity for V(V) binding through the phenolato and imino moieties, with the remainder of the available coordination sites potentially being taken up by two doubly bonded oxido groups and the alcoholic moieties attached to the Schiff core. The presence of the tethered alcoholic moieties also serves the purpose of providing the opportunity to the ligand, in its bound form to V(V), to seek and establish interactions (i.e. through hydrogen bonding or binding) with cellular targets, thereby facilitating V(V) reactivity exemplified through atoxicity, cell differentiation and/or insulin mimetic activity. Thus, the synthesis of the organic ligands and the ensuing binary hybrid materials is intimately linked to the potential role that they might exhibit, as bound ligands to V(V), in investigating and evaluating the biochemical reactivity of that metal ion. Synthetic implementation of that idea led to the use of a common source of [VO(C5H7O2)] as a synthon containing acetylacetonato groups. Under appropriate reaction conditions, materials 1-3 emerged and were isolated in single crystalline form. In all cases, oxidation of V(IV) to V(V) takes place as a predominant process leading to the emergence of the ultimately isolated [V(V)O2]+-containing complex assemblies. The physicochemical characterization of both the ligands and the corresponding materials 1-3 relied on elemental analysis, FT-IR, ESI-MS, NMR and X-ray crystallography, thereby providing a solid basis for their employment in the ensuing biological experiments. The species arising in solution are consistent with the dissolution of the polymeric architecture of the three materials and the rise of the mononuclear assemblies in each case.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0150">Structural identity association with potential biological activity</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0340" view="all">The arising ternary compounds of V(V), i.e. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, preserve the basic features present in the free ligands and stand appropriately and structurally configured so as to reflect well-defined species seeking biochemical and biological activities at the molecular level. In this regard, the three compounds have several key features enabling their classification in the same family of species. Common features in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> include the following: a) they all contain one Schiff ligand per V(V) ion (compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains 2 ligands per two vanadium centers in the solid state), b) in all three compounds, the Schiff ligand is doubly deprotonated, with the first site being the phenolic group and the second one being one of the alcoholic moieties, and c) the deprotonated alcoholic moiety is the one participating in V(V) binding, with the remaining alcoholic arms abstaining from coordination and dangling away from the V(V) center. In this respect, the only deprotonated alcoholic moiety in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> binds V(V), with the remaining two staying free. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, one of the alcoholic moieties is bound to V(V) in its deprotonated form, whereas the second one stands afar from the V(V) center. In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the only alcoholic moiety present and deprotonated is bound to V(V).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural identity association with potential biological activity

The arising ternary compounds of V(V), i.e. 1-3, preserve the basic features present in the free ligands and stand appropriately and structurally configured so as to reflect well-defined species seeking biochemical and biological activities at the molecular level. In this regard, the three compounds have several key features enabling their classification in the same family of species. Common features in 1-3 include the following: a) they all contain one Schiff ligand per V(V) ion (compound 1 contains 2 ligands per two vanadium centers in the solid state), b) in all three compounds, the Schiff ligand is doubly deprotonated, with the first site being the phenolic group and the second one being one of the alcoholic moieties, and c) the deprotonated alcoholic moiety is the one participating in V(V) binding, with the remaining alcoholic arms abstaining from coordination and dangling away from the V(V) center. In this respect, the only deprotonated alcoholic moiety in 1 binds V(V), with the remaining two staying free. In 2, one of the alcoholic moieties is bound to V(V) in its deprotonated form, whereas the second one stands afar from the V(V) center. In 3, the only alcoholic moiety present and deprotonated is bound to V(V).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0345" view="all">The aforementioned description of the three molecules reveals differences among the species in the solid state that include the following: a) compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possess solvent molecules bound to sodium ions, with the exception of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, b) variable coordination numbers for sodium ions interjecting abutting assemblies through available oxido and other alkoxido bridges, c) variable lattice dimensionalities varying from 3D (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) to 1D (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), likely denoting the importance of three alcoholic functionalities in the emergence of structural architecture, and c) a variable number of free alcoholic tethers, thereby projecting potentially differing-variable capacities for interactions (i.e. hydrogen bonding) with cellular targets. Collectively, the outlined similarities and differences in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> point out some of the factors that might influence individually the activity of the three species at the biological level in terms of toxicity and cellular differentiation related to insulin-mimetic activity toward fibroblast differentiation (vide infra). Undoubtedly, however, the common structural characteristics of the three materials support their subsequent use as distinct vanadoforms exerting biological effects on pre-adipocyte physiology and metabolism. Concurrently, the common structural features in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> set the stage for a meaningful chemical comparison of their solid state properties, potentially extending corresponding comparisons in their biological reactivity profiles toward pre-adipocyte to mature adipocyte differentiation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The aforementioned description of the three molecules reveals differences among the species in the solid state that include the following: a) compounds 1 and 2 possess solvent molecules bound to sodium ions, with the exception of 3, b) variable coordination numbers for sodium ions interjecting abutting assemblies through available oxido and other alkoxido bridges, c) variable lattice dimensionalities varying from 3D (1) to 1D (2 and 3), likely denoting the importance of three alcoholic functionalities in the emergence of structural architecture, and c) a variable number of free alcoholic tethers, thereby projecting potentially differing-variable capacities for interactions (i.e. hydrogen bonding) with cellular targets. Collectively, the outlined similarities and differences in 1-3 point out some of the factors that might influence individually the activity of the three species at the biological level in terms of toxicity and cellular differentiation related to insulin-mimetic activity toward fibroblast differentiation (vide infra). Undoubtedly, however, the common structural characteristics of the three materials support their subsequent use as distinct vanadoforms exerting biological effects on pre-adipocyte physiology and metabolism. Concurrently, the common structural features in 1-3 set the stage for a meaningful chemical comparison of their solid state properties, potentially extending corresponding comparisons in their biological reactivity profiles toward pre-adipocyte to mature adipocyte differentiation.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0155">Vanadium-potentiated biological activity</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0350" view="all">Vanadium has been shown to mimic insulin action in several ways (e.g. increase of lipogenesis, blood glucose lowering, inhibition of lipolysis). In this regard, the insulin-like effect of the well-defined and characterized synthetic binary V(V) compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was investigated with respect to the induction of pre-adipocyte cell differentiation. Of primary importance, to this end, was the atoxicity of the candidate V(V) compounds toward the 3T3-L1 (pre)adipocyte in the concentration range 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM. The results, clearly demonstrate the adipogenic potential of vanadium compounds. Initially, the simple KVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> salt was employed to evaluate toxicity in a concentration-dependent fashion. The results suggest that V(V) alone (in the form of VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup>) reduces cell viability. Experimentation with the ligands alone and the complexed vanadoforms, bearing variably structured aminoalcoholic moieties, ensued to probe the influence of the organic substrate on the bioactivity of the complex binary species. The cytotoxic profile of each ligand alone (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H–L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H) in the concentration range (1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) clearly shows dependence on the nature and number of alcohol arms in the molecule(s). To this end, ligands L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H are atoxic in the 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ range, with L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H being clearly toxic in the same range. Interestingly, the binary complex V(V)–[L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>] does not appear to be toxic in the same concentration range (vide infra). Examination of the three vanadoforms in <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> cultures took place in a concentration dependent fashion (1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) over a period of 24 h. The results suggest that the cytotoxic effects of V(V) ion are significantly reduced through complexation. In fact, all three V(V) compounds appear to be atoxic in the concentration range of 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for 24 h and the concentration range 1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Thus, it follows that the nature of substrates L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H–L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H bound to V(V) is crucial to the biological role that it exerts and pre-adipocyte survival. Based on the aforementioned cytotoxicity profile of the title compounds in pre-adipocytes over a period of 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, work on mature adipocytes post-differentiation (with insulin) ensued over a period of 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Treatment with the title compounds showed that cytotoxicity starts settling in at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is atoxic in the same concentration range of 1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Vanadium-potentiated biological activity

Vanadium has been shown to mimic insulin action in several ways (e.g. increase of lipogenesis, blood glucose lowering, inhibition of lipolysis). In this regard, the insulin-like effect of the well-defined and characterized synthetic binary V(V) compounds 1-3 was investigated with respect to the induction of pre-adipocyte cell differentiation. Of primary importance, to this end, was the atoxicity of the candidate V(V) compounds toward the 3T3-L1 (pre)adipocyte in the concentration range 1-100μM. The results, clearly demonstrate the adipogenic potential of vanadium compounds. Initially, the simple KVO3 salt was employed to evaluate toxicity in a concentration-dependent fashion. The results suggest that V(V) alone (in the form of VO3 -) reduces cell viability. Experimentation with the ligands alone and the complexed vanadoforms, bearing variably structured aminoalcoholic moieties, ensued to probe the influence of the organic substrate on the bioactivity of the complex binary species. The cytotoxic profile of each ligand alone (L1H-L3H) in the concentration range (1-100μΜ) clearly shows dependence on the nature and number of alcohol arms in the molecule(s). To this end, ligands L1H and L2H are atoxic in the 1-100μΜ range, with L3H being clearly toxic in the same range. Interestingly, the binary complex V(V)-[L3H-1] does not appear to be toxic in the same concentration range (vide infra). Examination of the three vanadoforms in in vitro cultures took place in a concentration dependent fashion (1-100μΜ) over a period of 24 h. The results suggest that the cytotoxic effects of V(V) ion are significantly reduced through complexation. In fact, all three V(V) compounds appear to be atoxic in the concentration range of 1-100μΜ for 24 h and the concentration range 1-50μΜ for 48h. Thus, it follows that the nature of substrates L1H-L3H bound to V(V) is crucial to the biological role that it exerts and pre-adipocyte survival. Based on the aforementioned cytotoxicity profile of the title compounds in pre-adipocytes over a period of 48h, work on mature adipocytes post-differentiation (with insulin) ensued over a period of 48h. Treatment with the title compounds showed that cytotoxicity starts settling in at 50μΜ for 2 and 3. Compound 1 is atoxic in the same concentration range of 1-50μΜ.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0355" view="all">Concurrently, in the general context of the influence of vanadium on the cytotoxicity of pre-adipocytes, a cell migration assay was also carried out for each complex vanadoform. The results reveal that of the three compounds, only <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not affect cell migration. Hence, albeit phenomenologically non-toxic, an agent (in this case a vanadoform) may affect endogenous cell motility, with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exemplifying such a bioactivity profile.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Concurrently, in the general context of the influence of vanadium on the cytotoxicity of pre-adipocytes, a cell migration assay was also carried out for each complex vanadoform. The results reveal that of the three compounds, only 1 does not affect cell migration. Hence, albeit phenomenologically non-toxic, an agent (in this case a vanadoform) may affect endogenous cell motility, with 1 exemplifying such a bioactivity profile.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0160">Cell differentiation by V(V)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0360" view="all">The adipogenic effect of insulin is one of the most fundamental functions of insulin signaling in adipose tissue and depends on several signaling molecules, including the insulin receptor substrates 1 and 2, phosphoinositol 3-kinase, and protein kinase B. The murine 3T3-L1 cell line is an established insulin-responsive pre-adipocyte model (capable of chemically induced differentiation) for the study of adipogenesis. On these grounds, the specific cell line has been justifiably used to investigate the differentiation potential of the title vanadium compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The results show that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> induce differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes in a concentration-dependent manner (1–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) similar to the effect induced by insulin itself, thereby demonstrating the adipogenic capacity of these compounds. In the case of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, differentiation proceeded in the same range of concentrations, with the maximum effect being observed at the lowest concentration (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cell differentiation by V(V)

The adipogenic effect of insulin is one of the most fundamental functions of insulin signaling in adipose tissue and depends on several signaling molecules, including the insulin receptor substrates 1 and 2, phosphoinositol 3-kinase, and protein kinase B. The murine 3T3-L1 cell line is an established insulin-responsive pre-adipocyte model (capable of chemically induced differentiation) for the study of adipogenesis. On these grounds, the specific cell line has been justifiably used to investigate the differentiation potential of the title vanadium compounds 1-3. The results show that 1 and 2 induce differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes in a concentration-dependent manner (1-20μΜ) similar to the effect induced by insulin itself, thereby demonstrating the adipogenic capacity of these compounds. In the case of 3, differentiation proceeded in the same range of concentrations, with the maximum effect being observed at the lowest concentration (1μΜ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0365" view="all">To confirm the successful differentiation process induced by vanadium, the specific biomarker GLUT 4 was employed, with its relative mRNA concentration determined through RT-PCR. The results reveal an increase in the expression of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT 4), in mature adipocytes differentiated with all three vanadium compounds, thereby proving the differentiation capacity of these complexes. GLUT 4 expression is an insulin dependent process. Consequently, once a cell is transformed into a mature adipocyte, GLUT 4 plays a major role in cell metabolic functions by allowing glucose transport into the cell, following stimulation by insulin. Proof of the aforementioned role comes from the observation that inhibition of adipogenesis results in decrease of GLUT 4  expression. Collectively, the results suggest that vanadium in its three complex forms stimulates differentiation arriving at mature adipocytes, in much the same way that insulin does, thereby indicating an insulin-like activity by the specific vanadoforms. Further in-depth examination of the results suggests that the above vanadium effects in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (of the metal ion) reach a 6.4-fold and a 10.4-fold increase, respectively, while insulin stands at a three-fold increase compared to untreated cells. In the case of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the maximum effect emerges at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM vanadium with an 11-fold increase compared to untreated cells.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To confirm the successful differentiation process induced by vanadium, the specific biomarker GLUT 4 was employed, with its relative mRNA concentration determined through RT-PCR. The results reveal an increase in the expression of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT 4), in mature adipocytes differentiated with all three vanadium compounds, thereby proving the differentiation capacity of these complexes. GLUT 4 expression is an insulin dependent process. Consequently, once a cell is transformed into a mature adipocyte, GLUT 4 plays a major role in cell metabolic functions by allowing glucose transport into the cell, following stimulation by insulin. Proof of the aforementioned role comes from the observation that inhibition of adipogenesis results in decrease of GLUT 4  expression. Collectively, the results suggest that vanadium in its three complex forms stimulates differentiation arriving at mature adipocytes, in much the same way that insulin does, thereby indicating an insulin-like activity by the specific vanadoforms. Further in-depth examination of the results suggests that the above vanadium effects in 1 and 2 at 20μΜ (of the metal ion) reach a 6.4-fold and a 10.4-fold increase, respectively, while insulin stands at a three-fold increase compared to untreated cells. In the case of 3, the maximum effect emerges at 1μM vanadium with an 11-fold increase compared to untreated cells.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0370" view="all">When cells were treated with a combination of insulin and one of the title compounds, there was no increase in the relative GLUT 4 mRNA expression, thereby indicating no enhancement synergistic effect of V(V) and insulin under the investigated conditions. In this regard, several studies support the fact that vanadium (vanadate) may alter or inhibit some of the insulin actions . Due to the paucity of information on the specific roles of the two partners in variable mechanistic pathways associated with adipocyte physiology, further work is needed (currently ongoing in our labs).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When cells were treated with a combination of insulin and one of the title compounds, there was no increase in the relative GLUT 4 mRNA expression, thereby indicating no enhancement synergistic effect of V(V) and insulin under the investigated conditions. In this regard, several studies support the fact that vanadium (vanadate) may alter or inhibit some of the insulin actions . Due to the paucity of information on the specific roles of the two partners in variable mechanistic pathways associated with adipocyte physiology, further work is needed (currently ongoing in our labs).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0375" view="all">The collective biological results indicate that a) the title compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are non-toxic in the range of 1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ both in pre- and mature adipocytes at two distinct time points (24 and 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h), b) do not affect cell migration (24 and 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h), and c) can induce cell differentiation in the μM range, thus mimicking insulin behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The collective biological results indicate that a) the title compounds 1-3 are non-toxic in the range of 1-50μΜ both in pre- and mature adipocytes at two distinct time points (24 and 48h), b) do not affect cell migration (24 and 48h), and c) can induce cell differentiation in the μM range, thus mimicking insulin behavior.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0165">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0380" view="all">Driven by a rationally designed approach to develop bioactive hybrid vanadodrugs against Diabetes mellitus, well-structured Schiff base ligands, bearing a systematically varying number of alcoholic moieties (1–3) linked to a sturdy vanillin core, were synthesized and subsequently employed in the synthesis of binary V(V)-Schiff compounds under specific stoichiometric conditions. The so derived materials <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> bear distinct architecture and lattice dimensionality properties, denoting the presence and influence of the terminal alcoholic moieties on the structural motifs, thereby configuring the geometrical and chemical reactivity attributes of the V(V) assemblies in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Assessment of the toxicity of the ligands alone and subsequently the solubilized materials led to the distinct differentiation of their biological profile toward 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes. Selection based on their observed (a)toxicity led to further employment in cell-differentiation studies, exemplifying for the first time the unique potentiation of V(V) in promoting pre-adipocyte differentiation toward mature adipocytes. This insulin-like behavior exhibited by vanadium was justifiably proven through use of biomarker-tagged GLUT 4 (as a downstream event in insulin activation pathway) mRNA expression levels, reflecting the potency of vanadium with regard to its differentiation potential and the functional status of the derived mature adipocytes poised toward glucose uptake and catabolism. That compound-specific property of vanadium was distinctly shown to occur in reflection of the nature and properties of the existing number of alcoholic moieties tethered to the vanillin core bound to V(V), thereby emphasizing their likely contribution to that metal ion's insulin-like bioactivity. Collectively, the data support a well-defined structure-specific V(V) biological activity toward adipogenesis, with the arising correlations formulating the basis of future efficient anti-diabetic vanadodrugs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Driven by a rationally designed approach to develop bioactive hybrid vanadodrugs against Diabetes mellitus, well-structured Schiff base ligands, bearing a systematically varying number of alcoholic moieties (1-3) linked to a sturdy vanillin core, were synthesized and subsequently employed in the synthesis of binary V(V)-Schiff compounds under specific stoichiometric conditions. The so derived materials 1-3 bear distinct architecture and lattice dimensionality properties, denoting the presence and influence of the terminal alcoholic moieties on the structural motifs, thereby configuring the geometrical and chemical reactivity attributes of the V(V) assemblies in 1-3. Assessment of the toxicity of the ligands alone and subsequently the solubilized materials led to the distinct differentiation of their biological profile toward 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes. Selection based on their observed (a)toxicity led to further employment in cell-differentiation studies, exemplifying for the first time the unique potentiation of V(V) in promoting pre-adipocyte differentiation toward mature adipocytes. This insulin-like behavior exhibited by vanadium was justifiably proven through use of biomarker-tagged GLUT 4 (as a downstream event in insulin activation pathway) mRNA expression levels, reflecting the potency of vanadium with regard to its differentiation potential and the functional status of the derived mature adipocytes poised toward glucose uptake and catabolism. That compound-specific property of vanadium was distinctly shown to occur in reflection of the nature and properties of the existing number of alcoholic moieties tethered to the vanillin core bound to V(V), thereby emphasizing their likely contribution to that metal ion's insulin-like bioactivity. Collectively, the data support a well-defined structure-specific V(V) biological activity toward adipogenesis, with the arising correlations formulating the basis of future efficient anti-diabetic vanadodrugs.

Found: V, 13.29; C, 41.51; H, 4.89; N 3.64.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0215">Preparation of complex {[(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]Na}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (3)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) in C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) ethanolamine (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.060<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added and the resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Then, it was cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.27<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) in C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.040<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the complex were grown by slow evaporation at 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.080<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (35%). Anal. calcd for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, {[(VO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]Na}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). (VC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>NNaO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, M<ce:inf loc="post">r</ce:inf> 317.15): V, 16.06; C, 37.87; H, 4.13; N 4.42. Found: V, 15.94; C, 37.53; H, 3.94; N 4.34.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0220">X-ray crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">X-ray quality crystals of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were grown from alcoholic solutions as stated above. A crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (0.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.29<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm) was taken from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>113<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with SHELXL-97 . Further experimental crystallographic details for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>130°; reflections collected/unique/used, 27,751/5463 [R<ce:inf loc="post">int</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0867]/5463; 508 parameters refined; (Δ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>/<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>

All hydrogen atoms were located by difference maps and were refined isotropically or were introduced at calculated positions as riding on bonded atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Plots of the structure were drawn using the Diamond 3 program package .</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of compounds

Preparation of L2H

To a solution of o-vanillin (3.0mmol, 0.46g) in methanol (30mL) 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (3.0mmol, 0.27g) was added under stirring. The emerging deep yellow solution was refluxed for 12h under continuous stirring and then was quickly cooled upon addition of room temperature ultrapure water. A pale yellow material precipitated and was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.25g (37%). Further confirmation of the identity of L2H in solution comes from ESI-MS measurements on solutions arising upon the dissolution of compound L2H in water (m/z=226.08, z=1, [MH]+) (Fig. S1).

Preparation of complex {(VO2)2(L1H-1)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n (1)

To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0mmol, 0.15g) in methanol (10mL) tromethamine (1.0mmol, 0.12g) was added. The resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2h at 90°C under continuous stirring and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C5H7O2)2] (1.0mmol, 0.27g) in methanol (10mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for additional 2h at 90°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (4.0mmol, 0.16g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the compound were grown by slow evaporation at 4°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.18g (45%). Calcd for 1, {[(VO2)2(L1H-1)2]Na2(CH3OH)2}n (1). (V2C26H38N2Na2O16, Mr 782.44): V, 13.02; C, 39.91; H, 4.90; N 3.58. Found: V, 12.99; C, 39.88; H, 4.83; N 3.44.

Preparation of complex {[(VO2)(L2H-1)]Na(C2H5OH)}n (2)

To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0mmol, 0.15g) in C2H5OH (10mL) 2-amino-1,3-propanediol (1.0mmol, 0.091g) was added and the resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2h at 90°C under continuous stirring. Then, it was cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C5H7O2)2] (1.0mmol, 0.27g) in C2H5OH (10mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (2.0mmol, 0.080g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the compound emerged through slow evaporation at 4°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.12g (31%). Anal. calcd for 2, {[(VO2)(L2H-1)]Na(C2H5OH)}n (2). (VC13H19NNaO7, Mr 375.23): V, 13.57; C, 41.61; H, 5.10; N 3.73. Found: V, 13.29; C, 41.51; H, 4.89; N 3.64.

Preparation of complex {[(VO2)(L3H-1)(H2O)]Na}n (3)

To a solution of o-vanillin (1.0mmol, 0.15g) in C2H5OH (10mL) ethanolamine (1.0mmol, 0.060mL) was added and the resulting yellow solution was refluxed for 2h at 90°C. Then, it was cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, a solution of [VO(C5H7O2)2] (1.0mmol, 0.27g) in C2H5OH (10mL) was added under continuous stirring. The resulting clear, green reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, NaOH (1.0mmol, 0.040g) was added. The resulting clear, brown reaction mixture was refluxed for an additional 2h at 90°C. Then it was cooled to room temperature. Yellow crystals of the complex were grown by slow evaporation at 4°C. The product was isolated by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 0.080g (35%). Anal. calcd for 3, {[(VO2)(L3H-1)(H2O)]Na}n (3). (VC10H13NNaO6, Mr 317.15): V, 16.06; C, 37.87; H, 4.13; N 4.42. Found: V, 15.94; C, 37.53; H, 3.94; N 4.34.

X-ray crystal structure determination

X-ray quality crystals of compounds 1-3 were grown from alcoholic solutions as stated above. A crystal of 1 (0.04×0.07×0.29mm) was taken from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to -113°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 with SHELXL-97 . Further experimental crystallographic details for 1: 2θ max =130°; reflections collected/unique/used, 27,751/5463 [Rint =0.0867]/5463; 508 parameters refined; (Δ/ σ)max =0.004; (Δρ)max /(Δρ)min =1.092/-0.898 e/Å3; R/Rw (for all data), 0.0958/0.2195. All hydrogen atoms were located by difference maps and were refined isotropically or were introduced at calculated positions as riding on bonded atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Plots of the structure were drawn using the Diamond 3 program package .

<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Crystal data and details of data collection and structure refinement for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Further experimental crystallographic details for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>30.41°; number of reflections collected/unique/used, 36,619/9797/5616 [R(int)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.021]; (Δ<ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>/<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(Δ<ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">min</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.46<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>/<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>0.64 e/Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>; R/R<ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf> (for all data), 0.0485/0.0828. Further experimental crystallographic details for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>32.68°; number of reflections collected/unique/used, 19,151/4596/3717 [R(int)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.025]; (Δ<ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>/<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(Δ<ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">min</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>/<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>0.37 e/Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>; R/R<ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf> (for all data), 0.0463/0.0847. Further details on the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given as Supplementary information in the form of cif files.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0245">Thermal studies</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0275" view="all">The thermal decomposition of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was studied by TGA under an atmosphere of oxygen (Fig. S9). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is thermally stable up to 97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 601<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule (Fig. S9-A). No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further. A plateau in the decomposition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is reached at 601<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with no further loss up to 850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0280" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is thermally stable up to 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 491<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-B). A plateau in the decomposition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is reached at 491<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with no further loss up to 850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0285" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is thermally stable up to 175<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Between 175<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 512<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-C). A plateau in the decomposition of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is reached at 512<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with no further loss up to 850<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0100">Cytotoxicity results</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st0105">V(V) cell toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0295" view="all">In an effort to examine whether V(V) ions (non-complexed inorganic vanadium) affect cell survival, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with 1, 10, 100, or 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of KVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (A<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). The results show that V(V) affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Specifically, reduction in cell survival is not affected at low concentrations (1, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) compared to the control, whereas reduction in cell survival amounts to 40% at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ and almost 50% at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control, exhibiting full reduction of cell survival under the employed experimental conditions.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0110">Ligand toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0300" view="all">To investigate the cytotoxic potential of the organic ligands–substrates L<ce:inf loc="post">i</ce:inf>H (i<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1–3) on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, the cells were treated with 1, 10, 100, 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H and L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H, respectively, for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h ( B-1 through B-3). The results show that L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Ιn particular, L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H causes reduction in cell survival amounting to 28% at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, 35% at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, 70% at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ and ><ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>90% at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05). Ligand L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H reduces cell survival only at the highest concentration (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ). Ligand L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H is not cytotoxic at all concentrations tested (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0135">V(V)-induced differentiation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0325" view="all">In an effort to investigate the insulin-mimetic activity, the title complexes were used to induce differentiation of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes according to standard protocol. All employed compounds induced differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes as assessed by oil Red O staining (1–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ). Differentiation was clearly evident at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM. The maximal effect was observed at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ, when cells were treated with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> appears to exert its maximal effect at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ. The effect of the three compounds tested was comparable to the differentiation effect induced by insulin (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ng/mL) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition, all three compounds were used at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ in combination with insulin, in an effort to probe potential synergistic interactions involving insulin and the title vanadium compounds. Of the three compounds, only <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showed evidence of differentiation exemplified through oil red O staining results. To further substantiate the differentiation of pre-adipocytes treated with V(V), RT-PCR was employed to assess the relative expression of GLUT 4 in mature adipocytes. To this end, differentiated mature adipocytes showed a 6.4-fold increase of GLUT 4 compared to undifferentiated pre-adipocytes (p<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.01), when treated with 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>). In the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there was a 10.4-fold increase when cells were treated with the same vanadium concentration. Interestingly, in the case of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the maximum effect was observed at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>11 fold). When insulin was used in the differentiation medium of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes in combination with one of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, mRNA expression grew limited in the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (compared to insulin), whereas in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the relative concentration of GLUT 4 mRNA was similar to that of insulin and the compound itself at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0155">Vanadium-potentiated biological activity</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0350" view="all">Vanadium has been shown to mimic insulin action in several ways (e.g. increase of lipogenesis, blood glucose lowering, inhibition of lipolysis). In this regard, the insulin-like effect of the well-defined and characterized synthetic binary V(V) compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was investigated with respect to the induction of pre-adipocyte cell differentiation. Of primary importance, to this end, was the atoxicity of the candidate V(V) compounds toward the 3T3-L1 (pre)adipocyte in the concentration range 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM. The results, clearly demonstrate the adipogenic potential of vanadium compounds. Initially, the simple KVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> salt was employed to evaluate toxicity in a concentration-dependent fashion. The results suggest that V(V) alone (in the form of VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup>) reduces cell viability. Experimentation with the ligands alone and the complexed vanadoforms, bearing variably structured aminoalcoholic moieties, ensued to probe the influence of the organic substrate on the bioactivity of the complex binary species. The cytotoxic profile of each ligand alone (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H–L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H) in the concentration range (1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) clearly shows dependence on the nature and number of alcohol arms in the molecule(s). To this end, ligands L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H and L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H are atoxic in the 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ range, with L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H being clearly toxic in the same range. Interestingly, the binary complex V(V)–[L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:inf>] does not appear to be toxic in the same concentration range (vide infra). Examination of the three vanadoforms in <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> cultures took place in a concentration dependent fashion (1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ) over a period of 24 h. The results suggest that the cytotoxic effects of V(V) ion are significantly reduced through complexation. In fact, all three V(V) compounds appear to be atoxic in the concentration range of 1–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for 24 h and the concentration range 1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Thus, it follows that the nature of substrates L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>H–L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H bound to V(V) is crucial to the biological role that it exerts and pre-adipocyte survival. Based on the aforementioned cytotoxicity profile of the title compounds in pre-adipocytes over a period of 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, work on mature adipocytes post-differentiation (with insulin) ensued over a period of 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Treatment with the title compounds showed that cytotoxicity starts settling in at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is atoxic in the same concentration range of 1–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal data and details of data collection and structure refinement for 1-3 are summarized in  . Further experimental crystallographic details for 2: θ max =30.41°; number of reflections collected/unique/used, 36,619/9797/5616 [R(int)=0.021]; (Δρ)max /(Δρ)min =0.46/-0.64 e/Å3; R/Rw (for all data), 0.0485/0.0828. Further experimental crystallographic details for 3: θ max =32.68°; number of reflections collected/unique/used, 19,151/4596/3717 [R(int)=0.025]; (Δρ)max /(Δρ)min =0.34/-0.37 e/Å3; R/Rw (for all data), 0.0463/0.0847. Further details on the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given as Supplementary information in the form of cif files.

Thermal studies

The thermal decomposition of complexes 1-3 was studied by TGA under an atmosphere of oxygen (Fig. S9). Compound 1 is thermally stable up to 97°C. Between 97°C and 601°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule (Fig. S9-A). No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further. A plateau in the decomposition of 1 is reached at 601°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Compound 2 is thermally stable up to 35°C. Between 35°C and 491°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-B). A plateau in the decomposition of 2 is reached at 491°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Compound 3 is thermally stable up to 175°C. Between 175°C and 512°C, there is further weight loss, in line with the decomposition of the organic structure of the molecule. No clear plateaus are reached in these stages, suggesting that the derived products are unstable and decompose further (Fig. S9-C). A plateau in the decomposition of 3 is reached at 512°C, with no further loss up to 850°C.

Cytotoxicity results

V(V) cell toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

In an effort to examine whether V(V) ions (non-complexed inorganic vanadium) affect cell survival, 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes were treated with 1, 10, 100, or 200μΜ of KVO3 for 24h (A). The results show that V(V) affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Specifically, reduction in cell survival is not affected at low concentrations (1, 10μΜ) compared to the control, whereas reduction in cell survival amounts to 40% at 100μΜ and almost 50% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Sodium deoxycholate has been used as a positive control, exhibiting full reduction of cell survival under the employed experimental conditions.

Ligand toxicity in 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes

To investigate the cytotoxic potential of the organic ligands-substrates LiH (i=1-3) on 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes, the cells were treated with 1, 10, 100, 200μΜ of L1H, L2H and L3H, respectively, for 24h ( B-1 through B-3). The results show that L3H affects cell survival in a concentration-dependent manner (p<0.05). Ιn particular, L3H causes reduction in cell survival amounting to 28% at 1μΜ, 35% at 10μΜ, 70% at 100μΜ and >90% at 200μΜ (p<0.05). Ligand L1H reduces cell survival only at the highest concentration (200μΜ). Ligand L2H is not cytotoxic at all concentrations tested (p>0.05).

V(V)-induced differentiation

In an effort to investigate the insulin-mimetic activity, the title complexes were used to induce differentiation of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes according to standard protocol. All employed compounds induced differentiation of pre-adipocytes into mature adipocytes as assessed by oil Red O staining (1-20μΜ). Differentiation was clearly evident at 1μM. The maximal effect was observed at 20μΜ, when cells were treated with 1 and 2. Compound 3 appears to exert its maximal effect at 1μΜ. The effect of the three compounds tested was comparable to the differentiation effect induced by insulin (10ng/mL) ( ). In addition, all three compounds were used at 20μΜ in combination with insulin, in an effort to probe potential synergistic interactions involving insulin and the title vanadium compounds. Of the three compounds, only 3 showed evidence of differentiation exemplified through oil red O staining results. To further substantiate the differentiation of pre-adipocytes treated with V(V), RT-PCR was employed to assess the relative expression of GLUT 4 in mature adipocytes. To this end, differentiated mature adipocytes showed a 6.4-fold increase of GLUT 4 compared to undifferentiated pre-adipocytes (p<0.01), when treated with 20μΜ of 1 ( ). In the case of 2, there was a 10.4-fold increase when cells were treated with the same vanadium concentration. Interestingly, in the case of 3, the maximum effect was observed at 1μΜ (~11 fold). When insulin was used in the differentiation medium of 3T3-L1 pre-adipocytes in combination with one of 1-3, mRNA expression grew limited in the case of 1 and 2 (compared to insulin), whereas in 3 the relative concentration of GLUT 4 mRNA was similar to that of insulin and the compound itself at 20μΜ.

Vanadium-potentiated biological activity

Vanadium has been shown to mimic insulin action in several ways (e.g. increase of lipogenesis, blood glucose lowering, inhibition of lipolysis). In this regard, the insulin-like effect of the well-defined and characterized synthetic binary V(V) compounds 1-3 was investigated with respect to the induction of pre-adipocyte cell differentiation. Of primary importance, to this end, was the atoxicity of the candidate V(V) compounds toward the 3T3-L1 (pre)adipocyte in the concentration range 1-100μM. The results, clearly demonstrate the adipogenic potential of vanadium compounds. Initially, the simple KVO3 salt was employed to evaluate toxicity in a concentration-dependent fashion. The results suggest that V(V) alone (in the form of VO3 -) reduces cell viability. Experimentation with the ligands alone and the complexed vanadoforms, bearing variably structured aminoalcoholic moieties, ensued to probe the influence of the organic substrate on the bioactivity of the complex binary species. The cytotoxic profile of each ligand alone (L1H-L3H) in the concentration range (1-100μΜ) clearly shows dependence on the nature and number of alcohol arms in the molecule(s). To this end, ligands L1H and L2H are atoxic in the 1-100μΜ range, with L3H being clearly toxic in the same range. Interestingly, the binary complex V(V)-[L3H-1] does not appear to be toxic in the same concentration range (vide infra). Examination of the three vanadoforms in in vitro cultures took place in a concentration dependent fashion (1-100μΜ) over a period of 24 h. The results suggest that the cytotoxic effects of V(V) ion are significantly reduced through complexation. In fact, all three V(V) compounds appear to be atoxic in the concentration range of 1-100μΜ for 24 h and the concentration range 1-50μΜ for 48h. Thus, it follows that the nature of substrates L1H-L3H bound to V(V) is crucial to the biological role that it exerts and pre-adipocyte survival. Based on the aforementioned cytotoxicity profile of the title compounds in pre-adipocytes over a period of 48h, work on mature adipocytes post-differentiation (with insulin) ensued over a period of 48h. Treatment with the title compounds showed that cytotoxicity starts settling in at 50μΜ for 2 and 3. Compound 1 is atoxic in the same concentration range of 1-50μΜ.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para id="p0365" view="all">To confirm the successful differentiation process induced by vanadium, the specific biomarker GLUT 4 was employed, with its relative mRNA concentration determined through RT-PCR. The results reveal an increase in the expression of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT 4), in mature adipocytes differentiated with all three vanadium compounds, thereby proving the differentiation capacity of these complexes. GLUT 4 expression is an insulin dependent process. Consequently, once a cell is transformed into a mature adipocyte, GLUT 4 plays a major role in cell metabolic functions by allowing glucose transport into the cell, following stimulation by insulin. Proof of the aforementioned role comes from the observation that inhibition of adipogenesis results in decrease of GLUT 4  expression. Collectively, the results suggest that vanadium in its three complex forms stimulates differentiation arriving at mature adipocytes, in much the same way that insulin does, thereby indicating an insulin-like activity by the specific vanadoforms. Further in-depth examination of the results suggests that the above vanadium effects in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μΜ (of the metal ion) reach a 6.4-fold and a 10.4-fold increase, respectively, while insulin stands at a three-fold increase compared to untreated cells. In the case of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the maximum effect emerges at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM vanadium with an 11-fold increase compared to untreated cells.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: To confirm the successful differentiation process induced by vanadium, the specific biomarker GLUT 4 was employed, with its relative mRNA concentration determined through RT-PCR. The results reveal an increase in the expression of glucose transporter 4 (GLUT 4), in mature adipocytes differentiated with all three vanadium compounds, thereby proving the differentiation capacity of these complexes. GLUT 4 expression is an insulin dependent process. Consequently, once a cell is transformed into a mature adipocyte, GLUT 4 plays a major role in cell metabolic functions by allowing glucose transport into the cell, following stimulation by insulin. Proof of the aforementioned role comes from the observation that inhibition of adipogenesis results in decrease of GLUT 4  expression. Collectively, the results suggest that vanadium in its three complex forms stimulates differentiation arriving at mature adipocytes, in much the same way that insulin does, thereby indicating an insulin-like activity by the specific vanadoforms. Further in-depth examination of the results suggests that the above vanadium effects in 1 and 2 at 20μΜ (of the metal ion) reach a 6.4-fold and a 10.4-fold increase, respectively, while insulin stands at a three-fold increase compared to untreated cells. In the case of 3, the maximum effect emerges at 1μM vanadium with an 11-fold increase compared to untreated cells.
